Note that in the case of Down And Right, the movement distance is calculated on one axis. So, for a movement distance of 14 blocks, the platform will move 14 blocks down and 14 blocks right.

list.title: Movement Distance
list.comment: This determines the distance the platform will move.

list.title: Speed
list.comment: This determines the speed the platform will travel.
list.comment2: Note that higher values are the same as 2. For the diagonal direction, the speed is the same on both axes. The exact values in the directions that there is movement are as follows:[br]Fast: 1[br]Medium-Slow: 0.5[br]Slow: 0.25

checkbox.title: Z-Order
checkbox.comment: This will adjust the Z-Order of the platform in relation to other objects.
checkbox.comment2: Any non-zero value for this nybble will place the platform at Z-position -30.

checkbox.title: Event Activated
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the platform will only appear while the Triggering Event ID is activated.

checkbox.title: Move on Touch
checkbox.comment: Requires only a single player (as opposed to all players) to touch the platform before it starts moving.

sprite.name: (Unused) Swinging Castle Platform
sprite.notes: An unused platform that Nintendo ported from NSMB:DS. It requires certain settings to work correctly. It will swing back and forth as though it were attached to a Rotation Controller.

dependency.notes: Using large sizes is not recommended unless using sizehacks with other sprites.

value.title: Size
value.comment: This determines how large the platform is.
value.comment2: A setting of 0 is the same as a setting of 2. 1-15 provide general scaling from 50% to 750% scaling.

value.title: Speed
value.comment: This determines how quickly the platform will swing back and forth.

value.title: Swing Arc
value.comment: This determines how widely the platform will swing.

value.title: Initial Angle
value.comment: This determines the initial angle of the platform.

sprite.name: Lakitu Spawn Area
sprite.notes: Assigns a spawn area where Lakitu will continue to respawn while the player is inside it. Lakitu will follow the player along the top of the camera line and toss Spiny balls at the player to hinder their progress. The sprite's vertical position is used for Lakitu's height.

value.title: Location ID
value.comment: Lakitu respawn and chase the player only while a player is in this location.

checkbox.title: Delay
checkbox.comment: This flag makes Lakitu throw Spinies less often.
checkbox.advancedcomment: Used in Retail: 04-05 A1.

sprite.name: Climbing Koopa - Horizontal
sprite.notes:
A Koopa Troopa that clings to and walks around on Chainlink Fence type objects and terrain. This one only moves from left to right.
The Climbing Koopa requires a Chainlink Fence sprite or Chainlink Fence flagged Terrain objects in order to function. May not function with all types of Chainlink sprites.
sprite.yoshinotes: Yoshi can eat these Koopas and spit them out as a normal functioning Green Koopa exclusively.

dualbox.comment: This determines which type of Koopa Troopa will be on the fence. The red ones are slightly faster.

checkbox.title: Starts Behind Fence
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the Climbing Koopa will be placed on the reverse side of the Chainlink Fence.

sprite.name: Climbing Koopa - Vertical
sprite.notes:
A Koopa Troopa that clings to and walks around on Chainlink Fence type objects and terrain. This one only moves up and down.
The Climbing Koopa requires a Chainlink Fence sprite or Chainlink Fence flagged Terrain objects in order to function. May not function with all types of Chainlink sprites.
sprite.yoshinotes: Yoshi can eat these Koopas and spit them out as a normal functioning Green Koopa exclusively.

dualbox.comment: This determines which type of Koopa Troopa will be on the fence. The red ones are slightly faster.

checkbox.title: Starts Behind Fence
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the Climbing Koopa will be placed on the reverse side of the Chainlink Fence.

sprite.name: Chainlink Fence Flip Panel - Small
sprite.notes: This is the only way to reach the backside of a section of Chainlink Fence.

sprite.name: Chainlink Fence Flip Panel - Long
sprite.notes: This is the only way to reach the backside of a section of Chainlink Fence.

sprite.name: Paddle Wheel Platform
sprite.notes: A 4-platform set creating a sort of wheel which will 'spin' and move based on where the players are standing.

dualbox.comment: This determines which type of movement the platform will use.
dualbox.comment2:
Left and Right: The platform will move to the left or right as it spins until it hits a wall. When it does, it will stop spinning.

Line Controlled: The platform will move left and right along a Line and when it reaches an end point, it will continue to spin unless blocked by a wall.

checkbox.title: Event Activated
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the platform will only appear if the Triggering Event ID is activated.

sprite.name: Wiggler
sprite.notes: A normal sized Wiggler enemy. He does Wiggler things. Wiggle wiggle.

sprite.name: Boo
sprite.notes: A standard loose Boo enemy. The Boo will chase the player when there is no player actively facing the Boo.

checkbox.title: Slightly Faster
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the Boo will move slightly faster towards the player.

checkbox.title: Always Despawn
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the Boo will despawn when it's off screen regardless of whether it's moving. When disabled, the Boo will only despawn if it's off-screen and not moving.

sprite.name: (Unused) Path Controlled TEST Platform 1
sprite.notes: An untextured unused test platform that is controlled by Path data. Very useful when trying to visually test the Path you are creating, as you can move your starting Entrance and change the Starting Node to test each individual segment.

dependency.notes: A Use Paths Movement Controller is required to make use of this test platform. Also, using the larger sizes is not recommended unless using sizehacks with other sprites.

value.title: Height
value.comment: This determines the height of the test platform.

value.title: Width
value.comment: This determines the width of the test platform.

value.title: Path Movement ID
value.comment: Match the Path Movement ID with Sprite 159 in order to use this test platform.

value.title: Starting Node
value.comment: This determines which Node along the Path the test platform will start on.

list.title: At the End...
list.comment: This determines what the behavior of the test platform will be when it reaches the final Node of the Path it is travelling.

value.title: "Jump to" Node
value.comment: This determines which Node along the Path the test platform will return to after reaching the end of the Path.

sprite.name: Wobble Rock Platform
sprite.notes: An 'unstable' platform that requires the player to balance it once touching it in order to keep it from completely falling.

sprite.name: Unstable Hanging Chained Platform
sprite.notes: An 'unstable' large platform that will fall while a player stands on it, as well as tilt and wobble. The falling distance is 2½ blocks for the first player, and 1½ blocks more for additional players.

list.title: Tilt Distance
list.comment: This determines the instability of the platform, defining how many blocks the platform will tilt when a player is standing on the edge of it. This distance is only accurate for a single player, and increases by ~1 block when there are additional players on the middle of the platform.

list.title: Number of Cannon Pieces
list.comment: The bottom piece, starting at the Sprite's placement, corresponds to the last checkbox for each option below, and the top piece (when set to 7) will correspond to the first checkbox below.

multidualbox.comment:
Top <---> Bottom, Bottom First
This determines what type of segment is used.
multidualbox.comment2: If set to Cannon, the piece will be a Cannon that fires normal Bullet Bills. If set to Pole, the piece will be turned into a metal pole segment.

multidualbox.comment:
Top <---> Bottom, Bottom First
This determines which initial direction the Cannon Piece will face.
multidualbox.comment2: Pole segments are not visually affected by this setting.

multidualbox.comment:
Top <---> Bottom, Bottom First
This determines which direction the piece will rotate as viewed from above.

sprite.name: Skewer - Down
sprite.notes: A large spiked pillar that visually spins as it launches itself across a specific path.

dualbox.comment: This determines the color of the Skewer.

list.title: Travel Distance
list.comment: This determines the distance the Skewer will travel.

list.title: Speed
list.comment: This determines the speed in which the Skewer will cover its Travel Distance.

value.title: Delay Before Launch
value.comment: This determines the delay before the Skewer shoots out in its direction. A value of 1 is 10 frames of delay. A reminder that the game runs at 60 frames per second, and the game's clock is 44 frames per tick.

value.title: Delay Before Return
value.comment: This determines the delay before the Skewer returns to its starting position. A value of 1 is 10 frames of delay. A reminder that the game runs at 60 frames per second, and the game's clock is 44 frames per tick.

value.title: Timing Offset
value.comment: This determines the delay factor relevant to other otherwise identical Skewers.
value.comment2: A value of 8 is expected to have the opposite timing of a value of 0. Other delay values are fractional.
value.advancedcomment: ASM research is required to find the true details of this setting. Nintendo uses values of 0, 1, and 8. Don't be afraid to experiment.

checkbox.title: Make Sparks At End
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the Skewer will throw off sparks when it reaches the end of its Travel Distance.
checkbox.comment2: When having two Skewers 'collide', it's recommended that only one have this setting.

checkbox.title: Silent
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the Skewer will not create any sound effects.
checkbox.comment2: When having two Skewers 'collide', it's recommended that one of them has this setting enabled.

sprite.name: Water
sprite.notes:
Place this in the level to generate water. There are many different ways to use this type of Water.

Underwater Zone: If you just want to create an underwater zone, check Flat Top and leave everything else blank. Then place the Water about 6 blocks above your upper Zone boundary.

Moving Water: You can also create water that rises and/or falls. This gets a little complicated, so be sure to read the related settings.

Water Crest's Maximum Length: The crest of Water will stop drawing past 8192 pixels (512 blocks). You can avoid this by making multiple instances of Water in Locations. Make sure that the widths of the locations are no greater than 8192, and that they are multiples of 16.

dependency.notes: When using Moving Water, the Water becomes loaded across the entire Area instead of just the active Zone. Please build your levels with this in mind. Additionally, do not use more than one Moving Water in the same Area as only the top (highest Y-Axis) one will take effect. If you need Moving Water in multiple Zones within the same area, use [285] Rising and Falling Water instead. Also, be sure to reset your Sprite Settings if you switch between different setting groups of Moving Water or Location Water to prevent unusual bugs and behavior.

list.title: Moving Water - Rising Speed
list.comment: This determines the speed at which the Water will rise, or rise and fall.

list.title: Moving Water - Falling Speed
list.comment: This determines the speed at which the Water will fall.

list.title: I really wouldn't do that if I were you...
list.comment: Falling Water works in a peculiar way. When the appropriate event has not been activated, or there is no corresponding event, [Never ON] then the water surface will appear [Distance] blocks higher. The water will then sink this many blocks, respecting any delays. After waiting for the delay at the bottom, the water surface will not rise again. Not exactly. Instead, it will 'skip' the rising part and 'jump' to immediately to the top. Additionally, using this with events will cause the water to rise, instead of falling. [ON] But the starting point is the same higher distance. The difference is that the water rises continuously as long as the event is enabled. [Endless Rising] If it is disabled, [OFF after ON] the water surface will 'jump' back to where it started and remain there until the event is re-enabled. [Why bother?] Additionally, 1-5 on Movement Speed values have some additional odd glitchiness. Supposedly. So please, stop trying to combine settings like this. Or your level will suck.

dualbox.comment: This determines which direction the Water will move.
This determines which direction the Water will move while the Triggering Event is activated.
The Water will automatically rise and fall in accordance with the set delays.

dualbox.title1: Rises Distance while On, Falls when Off
dualbox.comment: The Water will rise the Distance value once activated, and stay at the top until the Triggering Event is deactivated. If the Triggering Event is deactivated before it rises the full distance, it will finish rising, then immediately start to fall.
dualbox.comment2: This option only applies if Delay values are both set to 0, Distance is set, and Triggering ID is set. Do not use [Extremely Buggy]. No really, don't. It won't help you any.

dualbox.title1: Rising and Falling while On, Glitch-Returns when Off
dualbox.comment: The Water will rise and fall in accordance with the set delays while the Triggering Event is activated.
dualbox.comment2: When the Triggering Event is deactivated, the Water will immediately return to its starting position in a glitchy manner. It is highly recommended to not cause this to happen in your level design. Use Event Chainers with Delays or the Event Looper to get this type of timing instead.

value.title: Moving Water - Distance
value.comment: This determines how many blocks the Water will move.
value.comment2: Setting this will drastically change the function of Moving Water. Please keep this in mind.

value.title: I wouldn't do that if I were you...
value.comment: This determines how many blocks the Water will move. Normally. But you are a bad person and are trying to set combinations of options that are known not to work. So stop right there and either change this back to zero, or select the option to the left of where it says [Extremely Buggy].

value.title: Moving Water - Delay at Top
value.comment: This determines the delay when the Water has finished rising.

value.title: Moving Water - Delay at Bottom
value.comment: This determines the delay when the Water has returned to its starting position.
value.comment2: The initial delay only can be set by using event-controlled Water. Utilize Event Chainers to fake the delay settings if you need to set an initial delay.

value.title: Moving Water - Triggering Event ID
value.comment: The Moving Water mode will be triggered when this Event is activated.

value.title: Location ID
value.comment: Match with a Location ID to set a specific area in which to display Water. Note that some sprites only work correctly in Non-Location Water.

checkbox.title: Higher Transparency and Flat Top
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the animated crest effect on the top portion of the Water is removed, and the Non-Location Water becomes almost transparent.

checkbox.title: Place Behind Layer 0
checkbox.comment: For this to work, 'Layer 0 Spotlight' must be turned off in the zone's settings.

checkbox.title: Unknown Flag 11.1
checkbox.comment: This flag makes the Water function differently to some degree. It is known to move up and down 1 tile on a cycle when this setting is used with a few others.

sprite.name: Lava
sprite.notes:
Place this in the level to generate lava. There are many different ways to use Lava.

Location Lava: If you assign a Location ID, you can cause lava to appear only within the chosen Location instead of across the entire stage.

Moving Lava: You can also create lava that rises and/or falls. This gets a little complicated, so be sure to read the related settings.

Lava Crest's Maximum Length: The crest of Lava will stop drawing past 8192 pixels (512 blocks). You can avoid this by making multiple instances of Location Lava. Make sure that the widths of the locations are no greater than 8192, and that they are multiples of 16.

dependency.notes: When using Moving Lava, the Lava becomes loaded across the entire Area instead of just the active Zone. Please build your levels with this in mind. Additionally, do not use more than one Moving Lava in the same Area as only the top (highest Y-Axis) one will take effect. Unlike with Moving Water you cannot use Moving Lava in multiple Zones within the same area, unless you place them at the same Y-Axis. Also, be sure to reset your Sprite Settings if you switch between different setting groups of Moving Lava or Location Lava to prevent unusual bugs and behavior.

list.title: Moving Lava - Rising Speed
list.comment: This determines the speed at which the Lava will rise, or rise and fall.

list.title: Moving Lava - Falling Speed
list.comment: This determines the speed at which the Lava will fall.

list.title: I really wouldn't do that if I were you...
list.comment: Right now, you've selected [Extremely Buggy]. You've made a terrible mistake somewhere and have combined the wrong settings.
list.comment2: Please don't try to set Distance or Delays while using Falling Lava. You will not like the results. Please trust me.
list.advancedcomment: Oh, so you turned on Advanced, did you? You think you're so smart... Well fine, I'll share the limited documentation we have on why you shouldn't use these settings: Falling Lava works in a peculiar way. When the appropriate event has not been activated, or there is no corresponding event, [Never ON] then the lava surface will appear [Distance] blocks higher. The lava will then sink this many blocks, respecting any delays. After waiting for the delay at the bottom, the lava surface will not rise again. Not exactly. Instead, it will 'skip' the rising part and 'jump' to immediately to the top. Additionally, using this with events will cause the lava to rise, instead of falling. [ON] But the starting point is the same higher distance. The difference is that the lava rises continuously as long as the event is enabled. [Endless Rising] If it is disabled, [OFF after ON] the lava surface will 'jump' back to where it started and remain there until the event is re-enabled. [Why bother?] Additionally, 1-5 on Movement Speed values have some additional odd glitchiness. Supposedly. So please, stop trying to combine settings like this. Or your level will suck.

dualbox.comment: This determines which direction the Lava will move.
This determines which direction the Lava will move while the Triggering Event is activated.
The Lava will automatically rise and fall in accordance with the set delays.

dualbox.title1: [???] Rises Distance while On, Falls when Off
dualbox.comment: The Lava will rise the Distance value once activated, and stay at the top until the Triggering Event is deactivated. If the Triggering Event is deactivated before it rises the full distance, it will finish rising, then immediately start to fall.
dualbox.comment2: This option only applies if Delay values are both set to 0, Distance is set, and Triggering ID is set. Do not use [Extremely Buggy]. No really, don't. It won't help you any.

dualbox.title1: [???] Rising and Falling while On, Glitch-Returns when Off
dualbox.comment: The Lava will rise and fall in accordance with the set delays while the Triggering Event is activated.
dualbox.comment2: When the Triggering Event is deactivated, the Lava will immediately return to its starting position in a glitchy manner. It is highly recommended to not cause this to happen in your level design. Use Event Chainers with Delays or the Event Looper to get this type of timing instead.

value.title: Moving Lava - Distance
value.comment: This determines how many blocks the Lava will move.
value.comment2: Setting this will drastically change the function of Moving Lava. Please keep this in mind.

value.title: I wouldn't do that if I were you...
value.comment: This determines how many blocks the Lava will move. Normally. But you are a bad person and are trying to set combinations of options that are known not to work. So stop right there and either change this back to zero, or select the option to the left of where it says [Extremely Buggy].

value.title: Moving Lava - Delay at Top
value.comment: This determines the delay when the Lava has finished rising.

value.title: Moving Lava - Delay at Bottom
value.comment: This determines the delay when the Lava has returned to its starting position.
value.comment2: The initial delay only can be set by using event-controlled Lava. Utilize Event Chainers to fake the delay settings if you need to set an initial delay.

value.title: Moving Lava - Triggering Event ID
value.comment: The Moving Lava mode will be triggered when this Event is activated.

value.title: Location Lava - Location ID
value.comment: Match with a Location ID to set a specific area in which to display Lava.
value.comment2: Note that some sprites only work correctly in Non-Location Lava.
value.advancedcomment: Location Lava only works properly with Location IDs 0-127. Location IDs 128-255 will cause the Lava to constantly move up and down slightly. It's unknown if a use can be found for this, so it remains documented here in the Advanced Comment.

checkbox.title: Location Lava - Flat Top
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the animated crest effect on the top portion of the Lava is removed. This creates a 'square' look.
checkbox.comment2: It's recommended to only use this when the Lava is touching a straight ceiling.

sprite.name: Skewer - Up
sprite.notes: A large spiked pillar that visually spins as it launches itself across a specific path.

dualbox.comment: This determines the color of the Skewer.

list.title: Travel Distance
list.comment: This determines the distance the Skewer will travel.

list.title: Speed
list.comment: This determines the speed in which the Skewer will cover its Travel Distance.

value.title: Delay Before Launch
value.comment: This determines the delay before the Skewer shoots out in its direction. A value of 1 is 10 frames of delay. A reminder that the game runs at 60 frames per second, and the game's clock is 44 frames per tick.

value.title: Delay Before Return
value.comment: This determines the delay before the Skewer returns to its starting position. A value of 1 is 10 frames of delay. A reminder that the game runs at 60 frames per second, and the game's clock is 44 frames per tick.

value.title: Timing Offset
value.comment: This determines the delay factor relevant to other otherwise identical Skewers.
value.comment2: A value of 8 is expected to have the opposite timing of a value of 0. Other delay values are fractional.
value.advancedcomment: ASM research is required to find the true details of this setting. Nintendo uses values of 0, 1, and 8. Don't be afraid to experiment.

checkbox.title: Make Sparks At End
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the Skewer will throw off sparks when it reaches the end of its Travel Distance.
checkbox.comment2: When having two Skewers 'collide', it's recommended that only one have this setting.

checkbox.title: Silent
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the Skewer will not create any sound effects.
checkbox.comment2: When having two Skewers 'collide', it's recommended that one of them has this setting enabled.

sprite.name: Skewer - Right
sprite.notes: A large spiked pillar that visually spins as it launches itself across a specific path.

dualbox.comment: This determines the color of the Skewer.

list.title: Travel Distance
list.comment: This determines the distance the Skewer will travel.

list.title: Speed
list.comment: This determines the speed in which the Skewer will cover its Travel Distance.

value.title: Delay Before Launch
value.comment: This determines the delay before the Skewer shoots out in its direction. A value of 1 is 10 frames of delay. A reminder that the game runs at 60 frames per second, and the game's clock is 44 frames per tick.

value.title: Delay Before Return
value.comment: This determines the delay before the Skewer returns to its starting position. A value of 1 is 10 frames of delay. A reminder that the game runs at 60 frames per second, and the game's clock is 44 frames per tick.

value.title: Timing Offset
value.comment: This determines the delay factor relevant to other otherwise identical Skewers.
value.comment2: A value of 8 is expected to have the opposite timing of a value of 0. Other delay values are fractional.
value.advancedcomment: ASM research is required to find the true details of this setting. Nintendo uses values of 0, 1, and 8. Don't be afraid to experiment.

checkbox.title: Make Sparks At End
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the Skewer will throw off sparks when it reaches the end of its Travel Distance.
checkbox.comment2: When having two Skewers 'collide', it's recommended that only one have this setting.

checkbox.title: Silent
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the Skewer will not create any sound effects.
checkbox.comment2: When having two Skewers 'collide', it's recommended that one of them has this setting enabled.

sprite.name: Skewer - Left
sprite.notes: A large spiked pillar that visually spins as it launches itself across a specific path.

dualbox.comment: This determines the color of the Skewer.

list.title: Travel Distance
list.comment: This determines the distance the Skewer will travel.

list.title: Speed
list.comment: This determines the speed in which the Skewer will cover its Travel Distance.

value.title: Delay Before Launch
value.comment: This determines the delay before the Skewer shoots out in its direction. A value of 1 is 10 frames of delay. A reminder that the game runs at 60 frames per second, and the game's clock is 44 frames per tick.

value.title: Delay Before Return
value.comment: This determines the delay before the Skewer returns to its starting position. A value of 1 is 10 frames of delay. A reminder that the game runs at 60 frames per second, and the game's clock is 44 frames per tick.

value.title: Timing Offset
value.comment: This determines the delay factor relevant to other otherwise identical Skewers.
value.comment2: A value of 8 is expected to have the opposite timing of a value of 0. Other delay values are fractional.
value.advancedcomment: ASM research is required to find the true details of this setting. Nintendo uses values of 0, 1, and 8. Don't be afraid to experiment.

checkbox.title: Make Sparks At End
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the Skewer will throw off sparks when it reaches the end of its Travel Distance.
checkbox.comment2: When having two Skewers 'collide', it's recommended that only one have this setting.

checkbox.title: Silent
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the Skewer will not create any sound effects.
checkbox.comment2: When having two Skewers 'collide', it's recommended that one of them has this setting enabled.

sprite.name: Red Coin
sprite.notes: A red colored coin intended to be used as a counted collectible item that will award the player with a power-up item when they collect all 8.

dependency.notes: The suggested use is to have 8 Red Coins placed with the same Red Coin ID and Event ID as a matching [156] Red Coin Ring. <font color="red">A game crash will occur if you assign more than 8 Red Coins within the same Red Coin ID</font> and it is also not recommended to use either object for a purpose outside of the default, within a normal style level.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: When this Event ID is activated, the Red Coin will appear.

checkbox.title: Place Behind Other Sprites
checkbox.comment: When enabled, this changes the relative Z-Order of the Red Coin placing it further behind other sprites.

value.title: Red Coin ID
value.comment: When the player collects all 8 Red Coins from the same set, the game will reference a Red Ring with the same Red Coin ID to determine which item to award to all players. Value 0 is also a valid ID.
value.comment2: <font color="red">A game crash will occur if you assign more than 8 Red Coins within the same Red Coin ID</font>

sprite.name: Floating Barrel
sprite.notes: A floating barrel that can only be placed on a liquid surface. It will sink while a player is standing on it, but will pop back up once the player jumps off. The barrel can also flow with the unused water current controller.

dependency.notes: The Floating Barrel will not load when placed on the same screen as an entrance. Place the Floating Barrel where you want it to load using the liquid line, and it will spawn floating at the surface line of that body of liquid. It only works with non-Location liquids, and it does work with Moving liquids when placed correctly. Unlike Floating Coins / ? Blocks, it will also function with Rising/Falling Water. Lastly, it should be noted that the visual splash effect is always made of water.

checkbox.title: Initially Submerged
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the floating barrel will load partially submerged.

sprite.name: Chain Chomp
sprite.notes: A chain chomp enemy tied up to a 3 block pole. The pole must be ground-pounded 3 times to release the Chain Chomp and he will rampage in the direction he is freed destroying all block terrain in his path.
sprite.advancednotes: We're pretty sure there's no setting to change the height of the pole, but you're welcome to test a few values.

sprite.name: Coin
sprite.notes: Your most basic, most flexible, standard golden coin. Did you know that if the player collects 100 of them, he gets an extra life?

dependency.notes: If pairing the Coin for movement or other features, you'll likely need one of the sprites listed in the Dependency List. Additionally, if you're using one of the Behavior Types of a coin in a bubble (1, 2, 4) you MUST include [317] Enables Bubbles within each Zone it is used in.

list.title: Movement Type
list.comment: This determines which type of movement the Coin will be assigned.
list.comment2: Movement Types 2, and 9+ are unused or otherwise unknown.
list.advancedcomment: If you want to experiment with unknown Types, you will need to modify the Raw Data.

value.title: Path Movement ID
value.comment: If pairing the Coin with sprite 159, match the Path Movement ID to enable Path controlled movement.

value.title: Two Way Line ID
value.comment: If pairing the Coin with sprite 260, match the Two Way Line ID to enable Two Way synchronized movement.

value.title: Water Ball ID
value.comment: If pairing the Coin with sprite 205, match the Water Ball ID to enable Water Ball synchronized movement.

value.title: Set to Zero
value.comment: If pairing the Coin with sprite 474, no further action is needed to create Dancing synchronized movement.

value.title: Set to Zero
value.comment: If pairing the Coin with sprite 474, no further action is needed to create Dancing synchronized movement.

value.title: Mushroom ID
value.comment: If pairing the Coin with sprite 172, match the Mushroom ID to enable Mushroom Bolt controlled movement. It will be paired to the platform with the Bolt.

value.title: Mushroom ID
value.comment: If pairing the Coin with sprite 382, match the Mushroom ID to enable Mushroom Bolt controlled movement. It will be paired to the platform without the Bolt.

value.title: Collection ID
value.comment: If pairing the Coin with sprite 459/461, match the Collection ID to have the game count this Coin towards the Collection Set.

list.title: Behavior Type
list.comment: This determines the additional behavior of the Coin.
list.comment2:
Some coin types don't work together with a Movement Controller.

0 - A normal coin.
1 - Drifts horizontally in Mario's direction, inside a bubble.
2 - Sinks quickly in Mario's direction, inside a bubble.
3 - A loose coin, similar to those created when Mario kills an enemy with a Fire Flower.
4 - Sinks slowly in Mario's direction, inside a bubble.
5 - A loose coin, similar to those created when Mario kills an enemy with a Fire Flower. (May differ from 3?)
6 - Makes the bonus sound from a 10-Coin block bonus when the coin loads
7 - Floats upwards in Mario's direction
8 - Spins faster than a normal coin (?)
9 - Collected automatically when the coin loads
10 - Unknown effect, coin does not show.
11 - A loose coin that seems to fall from the sky
12 - A loose coin, similar to those created when Mario kills an enemy with a Fire Flower. (May differ from 3?)
13 - Unknown effect, coin does not show.
14 - Spins much faster than a normal coin
15 - Frozen inside of an ice block (can be melted by fireballs).
list.advancedcomment:
0: StateID_CoinWait;
3/5: State_Jump;
4: rlwinm Down, uses Nybble 11 (0, 1, 2);
6: State_BlockDownJump;
7: FiveBlockWait, uses Nybble 11 (0, 1, 2, 3);
8: Flags coin, 0/159/260;
9: DemoUp, uses Nybble 9 (PlayerID);
10: EggBlock;
11: State_Jump;
12: State_BlockJump;
13: StateID_Move, Very Similar to 0?;
14: WaterState;

checkbox.title: Place Behind Chainlink Fence
checkbox.comment: When enabled, this modifies the placement of the Coin so that the player must be on the other side of a Chainlink Fence to collect it.
checkbox.comment2: [What movement types does this work with? What movement types totally don't work with this? We need answers, MAN!]

checkbox.title: Place Behind Layer 1
checkbox.comment: When enabled, this modifies the Z-Order of the coin where it will be hidden behind all Layer 1 objects.
checkbox.comment2: [This is similar to the above option, but we have no clue how it differs or if this is just a normal Z-Order VALUE option.]

value.title: Unknown Value 8
value.advancedcomment: ASM: Something involving 'Direction' somehow.

list.title: Sinking Slowly in Bubble: Unknown Value 11
list.advancedcomment: ASM: Involves [Behavior Type 4] Only.

list.title: Floats Upwards: Unknown Value 11
list.advancedcomment: ASM: Involves [Behavior Type 7] Only.

value.title: Loose Coin [5]: Initial Movement Speed
value.comment: This sets [something relating to initial movement speed].
value.advancedcomment: ASM: Involves [Behavior Type 5] Only.

list.title: Awarded Player
list.comment: This determines which player will be awarded with the coin.

sprite.name: Springboard
sprite.notes: A springboard item that the player can bounce on to reach new heights, and can carry around with them.

checkbox.title: Does Not Despawn
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the Springboard will not despawn from being offscreen.
checkbox.comment2: Normally, the Springboard will vanish if it goes too far offscreen, but with this option it will remember where it was last at and not disappear.

checkbox.title: Place Behind Other Sprites
checkbox.comment: When enabled, this changes the relative Z-Order of the Springboard placing it further behind other sprites.

checkbox.title: Shift Spawn Position (NSMB:DS)
checkbox.comment: When enabled, this moves the Springboard half a block to the right.
checkbox.advancedcomment: This is a leftover setting from the NSMB:DS Springboard where sprites could only be placed exactly on the tile grid. It... really isn't useful.

sprite.name: Rotation Controller - Spinning
sprite.notes:
This controller will create synchronized movement between matched sprites and cause them to spin in a circular motion. It acts as the center of rotation for most sprites.
Additionally, it can control the Zone's Zoom level depending on the rotation controller's current rotation.

value.title: Rotation ID
value.comment: A Rotation ID isn't necessary when using this sprite to control the camera.

list.title: Starting Rotation
list.comment:
This determines the rotational adjustment for when items are first loaded or before the controller is activated.
The starting rotation can also set the Zone's Zoom level when it's loaded, by-passing the initial zoomed in camera.
list.comment2: For coins and blocks, the Starting Rotation value is doubled! This means that a value of 4 will rotate the coin or block 180°.

list.title: Rotation Speed
list.comment: Coins and Blocks rotate faster than other sprites.
list.comment2: The angular velocity is shown in parentheses, where 1 corresponds to 1/1024th pi radians per frame. That is, with speed 'Very Slow', a full rotation takes 2048 frames.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: When the Triggering Event is activated, the controller will rotate all associated objects according to the mode. Deactivation effects will also differ depending on the mode. See the ! Comment.
value.comment2:
Constant Spinning: When activated, the items will decelerate to a stop and accelerate in the opposite direction.
When deactivated, it will reverse back to its set movement in a similar fashion.

Stops and Returns: When activated, the items will rotate the Rotation Distance and stop. When deactivated, the items will immediately start to rotate back to their starting positions, even if the initial movement is not completed.

Spins While Active:
When activated, the items will rotate continuously. When deactivated, the items will stop at the next multiple of its set Rotation Distance.

list.title: Event Triggered - Rotation Distance
list.comment: This determines the distance the rotation controller will spin the items before stopping, when set to the [Stops and Returns] or [Spins While Active] Rotation Modes.

checkbox.title: Creates Fake POW-Block Effect
checkbox.comment: Makes a silent POW-Block screen shake each rotation.

checkbox.title: Creates Coin Sound Effect
checkbox.comment: Makes a Coin 'Sparkle' sound effect when linked to a Rotation Controlled Coin that has not been collected yet, each time it rotates.

checkbox.title: Controls the Zone's Zoom Level
checkbox.comment:
When enabled, the Zone's Zoom level will become fully dependant on the rotation controller's current angle. Thus, the camera will transition in accordance with the speed and current arc of the sprite. It supports all Rotation Modes, but works best with [Stops and Returns]. This is the pattern the Zoom Level will follow:

0° = Zooms to the Zone's original Zoom Level.
22.5° = Zooms out roughly to the next available Zoom Level.
45° = Zooms out roughly 70% towards Zoom Level 4.
67.5° = Zooms out roughly 95% towards Zoom Level 4.
90° = Zooms out exactly to Zoom Level 4.
112.5+° = The pattern above loops in reverse, ultimately back to the original Zoom level at 180°.

sprite.name: (Unused) Jumping Cheep Cheep
sprite.notes: <font color="orange">This sprite is not recommended for use due to incompatibilities with the Ice Flower power-up.</font>
sprite.advancednotes: A Cheep Cheep that will jump out of the water in an attempt to damage the player. If frozen, only half of the Cheep Cheep will be covered by ice, and the other part will stick out.

dependency.notes: Cannot be used without Water for the Cheep Cheep to live in.

checkbox.title: Alternate Movement
checkbox.comment: When enabled, after the first jump, the Cheep Cheep will not continue swimming but instead wait at the landing point to jump again.
checkbox.comment2: It ends up looking like the Cheep Cheep is 'stuck' in the water.

sprite.name: Porcupuffer
sprite.notes: A stand-alone Porcupuffer that will chase the player along the water line indefinitely until killed, but will not respawn.

dependency.notes: Water is required for the Porcupuffer to function. It must be non-location water, possibly non-moving water.

checkbox.title: Unknown Flag 11 (1)
checkbox.advancedcomment: ASM shows Nybble 11 might affect something.

sprite.name: Incomplete Sprite - 'En_Blur'
sprite.notes: Does nothing.

sprite.name: (Unused) ?-Switch
sprite.notes: An exact duplicate of the normal ?-Switch.

dependency.notes: The game will crash unless a normal orange switch is placed somewhere in the level. It does not have to be within an area that is actually used.

checkbox.title: Upside-Down
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the switch will be facing downwards.
checkbox.comment2: Upside-Down switches cannot be set to fall.

checkbox.title: Falls
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the switch will be movable by environmental factors, such as dropping down when bricks below it are destroyed, or moving along platforms.
checkbox.comment2: Conveyor belts cannot move Switches, even when [Falls] is set.

value.title: Target Event ID
value.comment: This event will be modified when the switch is pressed.

dualbox.comment: This determines how the Target Event is modified.
dualbox.comment2: The Target Event will be modified to the opposite state when the Timed effect expires.

dualbox.comment: This determines how the Target Event is modified.
This determines if the Target Event is modified temporarily or permanently.
dualbox.comment2: Permanent Event cannot be used with Multi-Use.

checkbox.title: Disable Music Interruption
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the switch will not interrupt the normal level music with Timed music. This setting is only applicable if Timed Event is set.

dualbox.comment: This determines if the switch will pop back up when the Timed effect expires.
dualbox.comment2:
Single Use: The switch will vanish entirely after pressed.

Multi-Use: The switch will enter a flat state. When the Timed effect expires, the switch will pop back up following the Delay setting.
dualbox.advancedcomment:
If the Target Event is deactivated/activated by another method, Multi-Use switches will flatten or pop-up on their own.

The pop up effect can be used to launch the player much higher than they could normally jump.

list.title: Delay on Multi-Use
list.comment: This determines how long the switch will take to pop up after the timer expires on a Timed Multi-Use switch.

checkbox.title: Loads at Midway
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the switch will only appear if the level has been loaded from a Midway point.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: This switch will not be visible if a Triggering Event is defined unless that event is activated.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: This switch will not be visible if a Triggering Event is defined unless that event is activated.
value.advancedcomment: Using a Triggering ID with Multi-Use functionality is somewhat glitchy and not recommended.

sprite.name: Porcupuffer Spawn Area
sprite.notes: Assigns a spawn area where Porcupuffers will continue to respawn while the player is inside it. Porcupuffers will follow the player along the water line.

dependency.notes: Water is required for the Porcupuffer to function. It must be non-location water, possibly non-moving water.

value.title: Location ID
value.comment: Porcupuffers respawn and chase the player only while a player is in this location.

value.title: Spawn Delay
value.comment: This determines how long it will take for the Porcupuffer to first appear after the player enters the Spawn Area.

value.title: Respawn Delay
value.comment: This determines how long it will take for the Porcupuffer to respawn after being killed.

sprite.name: Line Controlled Star Coin
sprite.notes: A variant of the Star Coin that will ride along Line objects.

dependency.notes: Use the Group Controller [236] for spawn synchronization with other Group controlled sprites.

list.title: Coin Number
list.comment: This determines which Star Coin flag will be set for the level when this Star Coin is collected.
list.comment2: If multiple Star Coins with the same number are placed, duplicate entries will not load if the player has already collected one that attempt.

value.title: Group ID
value.comment: This pairs the Star Coin to a matching Group Controller for spawn synchronization with other Group controlled sprites.

dualbox.comment: This determines which direction the Star Coin will move based on the Line that it is connected to.

list.title: Speed
list.comment: Line Controlled sprites use the same speed setting across all of them.

checkbox.title: Place Behind Other Sprites
checkbox.comment: When enabled, this changes the relative Z-Order of the Star Coin placing it further behind other sprites.

value.title: Target Event ID
value.comment: When the Star Coin is collected, the Target Event ID will be activated.

dualbox.comment: This determines if the Target Event is timed or permanent. Timed events will pause the music and replace it with ticking.

sprite.name: Red Coin Ring
sprite.notes: A glowing red ring that is intended to be used to spawn sets of 8 red coins, and to control the item that the player will receive after collection them.

dependency.notes: The suggested use is to have 8 [144] Red Coins placed with the same Red Coin ID and Event ID as a matching Red Coin Ring. It is not recommended to use more than 1 Red Coin Ring within a single Zone, nor is it recommended to use either object for a purpose outside of the default, within a normal style level.

value.title: Target Event ID
value.comment: When the Red Coin Ring is touched, the Target Event will be activated.

dualbox.comment: This determines if the Target Event is activated temporarily or permanently.
dualbox.comment2: Timed events will pause the music and replace it with ticking. It is recommended for normal Red Coin Ring use that the event be timed.

value.title: Red Coin ID
value.comment: When set, the corresponding Red Coin set will have an Item Reward. Value 0 is also a valid ID.

list.title: Item Reward
list.comment: This determines which power-up will appear after collecting 8 coins from the Red Coin ID set above. If a player already has a power-up, it will drop a 1-Up.

checkbox.title: Shift Horizontally
checkbox.comment: When this checkbox is ticked, the ring is moved half a block to the right. Note that this setting overlaps with the Red Coin ID.

checkbox.title: Unknown Flag 10 (1)
checkbox.advancedcomment: ASM shows Nybble 10 might affect something. No visible or functional change. Likely Z-Order related, or at least intended to be.

sprite.name: Big Brick Block
sprite.notes: No matter what is inside, this light-colored 3x3 brick block always breaks open. It can even be broken by small Mario.

list.title: Block Contains
list.comment: This determines if anything appears from inside the block when it is destroyed.

value.title: Withstands (Needs Multiple Hits)
value.comment: This determines the number of hits or ground-pounds needed for the block to break. For this function, a texture will be used that has some odd-looking white numbers on it.
value.advancedcomment: This setting may only apply to the original Giant Breakable Brick Block

sprite.name: Fire Snake
sprite.yoshinotes: While Yoshi cannot safely jump on this enemy, if he eats one he will spit out a fireball.
sprite.notes: A hopping fire enemy that will also affect the lighting in a dark Zone.

checkbox.title: Hides and Waits
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the Fire Snake will be a stationary ball of fire until the player approaches it.

checkbox.title: Unknown Flag 11 (1)
checkbox.advancedcomment: ASM shows Nybble 11 might affect something.

sprite.name: Movement Controller - Uses Paths
sprite.notes: A movement controller that connects certain sprites so they can be moved by Paths. Paths are a special type of data within the level structure that has speed, acceleration, and delay values built into each Node.

dependency.notes: The distance of this sprite to the first node of the Path will be imitated by all associated Path Controlled objects. This means that every linked object will be placed the same amount of blocks away from each node, identical to the distance of this sprite to its first node. It is therefore recommended to place this sprite directly on top of the first node, so that all controlled objects follow the path directly as drawn.

value.title: Path Movement ID
value.comment: This pairs matching 'Path Movement' controlled objects to this controller.

value.title: Path ID
value.comment: This determines the ID of the Path that the objects will be linked to.

value.title: Starting Node
value.comment: This determines the Node of the Path that the objects will start moving from.

dualbox.comment: This determines if the objects following this path will obtain their movement properties from a complex combination of previous nodes and the next node, or from the next node only.

list.title: At the end...
list.comment: This determines if the linked objects will stop at the end node of the Path or if they will loop (from a specifc node)
list.comment2: Stops: The objects stop moving.[br]Loops: The objects follow a straight line to the node indicated by 'Starting Node (Loop)', and then continue from there.[br]Stops (Intended Drop): A vertical acceleration of -0.15 is applied until the terminal velocity is reached. Note that this does not actually drop the objects, because the terminal velocity of this sprite has been set to 0.[br]???: Seems like unintended behaviour - the next node's data is read out of bounds. This could be the data of the next path node, or just garbage data. Depending on how the path data is stored in the level archive, this setting will connect all final nodes of path x with the initial node of path (x+1). The final node of the final path will connect with an imaginary path node at the top left of the canvas. However, it's best not to rely on this behaviour.

value.title: Starting Node (Loop)
value.comment: When the linked objects reach the end of the path, they will continue going in a straight line to this Node.

sprite.name: (Unused) Path Controlled TEST Platform 2
sprite.notes: An untextured unused test platform that is controlled by Path data. Very useful when trying to visually test the Path you are creating, as you can move your starting Entrance and change the Starting Node to test each individual segment. DATA FOR THIS SPRITE MAY BE COMPLETELY WRONG.

dependency.notes: A Use Paths Movement Controller is required to make use of this test platform. Also, using the larger sizes is not recommended unless using sizehacks with other sprites.

value.title: Height
value.comment: This determines the height of the test platform.

value.title: Width
value.comment: This determines the width of the test platform.

value.title: Path Movement ID
value.comment: Match the Path Movement ID with Sprite 159 in order to use this test platform.

value.title: Starting Node
value.comment: This determines which Node along the Path the test platform will start on.

list.title: At the End...
list.comment: This determines what the behavior of the test platform will be when it reaches the final Node of the Path it is travelling.

sprite.name: Pipe Bubbles
sprite.notes: A stream of bubbles that pushes the player away when underwater, as well as push a 'spin-jumped' Propeller power-up. It will also influence a normal spin jump for extra height.

dependency.notes: If not using the Enables Bubbles sprite, this will only generate 'wind' and not 'bubbles'.

list.title: Direction
list.comment: This determines the direction of the bubbles.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: When this Event is activated, the bubble jet will turn off allowing the player to access the pipe at the end.

sprite.name: Vertical Scroll Limiter 1 - Left Side
sprite.notes: This sprite allows you to limit how far the camera will scroll vertically by creating an imaginary horizontal border between a matching pair of Scroll Limiters. This can be used to create a deeper kill zone, hide secret areas, or otherwise restrict the camera in certain sections of a level.

dependency.notes: Place this on the left side of the area you want to limit, and place an identical [163] on the right side at the same height. This will create an independent, horizontal zone border located at the height of the Limit pair's placement.

value.title: Revoke Vertical Scroll Limit (Left)
value.comment: I don't know? Is apparently a VALUE, 0, 1, 2, 3+?

dualbox.comment: This determines which camera boundary will be restricted by this Limit pair.

checkbox.title: Permeable Scroll Limit
checkbox.comment: I know what purpose this has but this description sounds excessive and confusing. I need it boiled down!
checkbox.comment2: With this option, two new specific 'areas' are specified, above and below the scroll limit ('default area' and 'secret area'). Both areas touch the scroll border from the outside. If the bottom of a player's collision box leaves the original (default) area, the screen will quickly 'jump' to this new (secret) area. The shifting is independent of the height of the screen limit. The screen will be pushed up/down as far as needed, until the bottom of the screen is a certain number of blocks above/below the end of the original screen limit. || The required number of blocks between the bottom of the source region and the bottom of the screen is by default 5 (shifting upward) and 8 (for a downward shift). You can alter these values under 'Zone Settings' (Upper/Lower Bounds). || Shifting from the default area to the secret area above/below the scroll limit can be tweaked by changing values for 'Upper Bounds'. The opposite is true for 'Lower Bounds' (shifting from default area to the secret area below. The increase/decrease of the scrollable area reduces/enlarges the necessary distance to the same extent that is needed to pull off the shifting. |||| If Mario goes back to the default area, the screen will quickly follow and it will be locked to the default area as usual (unless Mario goes above/below the scroll limit once again to reach the secret area)... |||| This option can be used to set up secret zones that can only be seen if Mario reaches a specific position. This technique was used in many older Mario games, e.g. Super Mario Land 3: Wario Land. So if you are located below the screen, nothing happens. Only when jumping over the area, the screen scrolls up so you can hide secret paths there as you like. Similarly, one can also hide secret paths under the screen.

value.title: Scroll Limit Shifting in Restricted Direction
value.comment: I don't know what practical purpose this has?
value.comment2: Determines how far the screen can scroll above/below the scroll limit (in blocks). Somewhat flawed if used together with 'Permeable Scroll Limit'. The position where the scrolling will begin does not differ from a scroll limit with shifting of 0. So it looks as if the screen is scrolling faster with increasing values ​​when Mario approaches it. Even higher values are canceled entirely and have no effect because the scrolling is no longer necessary when the end of the screen is too far above or below the end of the original screen border. Nevertheless, the screen jumps to the end of the scroll border when entering the default area again. Only if the bottom of the screen is too far beyond the original area (or vice versa), then the screen is already at the end of the scroll border, and no shifting of the screen is needed.

checkbox.title: Unknown Flag 6 (1)
checkbox.advancedcomment: Used in Retail: 02-01 A1, 05-24 A1, 06-02 A4.

value.title: Unknown Value 10
value.advancedcomment: From ASM: An independent effect differing from [Permeable Scroll Limit]. Details have not been researched.

value.title: Unknown Value 12
value.advancedcomment: From ASM: An independent effect differing from [Permeable Scroll Limit]. Details have not been researched.

sprite.name: Vertical Scroll Limiter 1 - Right Side
sprite.notes: This sprite allows you to limit how far the camera will scroll vertically by creating an imaginary horizontal border between a matching pair of Scroll Limiters. This can be used to create a deeper kill zone, hide secret areas, or otherwise restrict the camera in certain sections of a level.

dependency.notes: Place this on the right side of the area you want to limit, and place an identical [162] on the left side at the same height. This will create an independent, horizontal zone border located at the height of the Limit pair's placement.

value.title: Revoke Vertical Scroll Limit (Right)
value.comment: I don't know? Is apparently a VALUE, 0, 1, 2, 3+?

dualbox.comment: This determines which camera boundary will be restricted by this Limit pair.

checkbox.title: Permeable Scroll Limit
checkbox.comment: I know what purpose this has but this description sounds excessive and confusing. I need it boiled down!
checkbox.comment2: With this option, two new specific 'areas' are specified, above and below the scroll limit ('default area' and 'secret area'). Both areas touch the scroll border from the outside. If the bottom of a player's collision box leaves the original (default) area, the screen will quickly 'jump' to this new (secret) area. The shifting is independent of the height of the screen limit. The screen will be pushed up/down as far as needed, until the bottom of the screen is a certain number of blocks above/below the end of the original screen limit. || The required number of blocks between the bottom of the source region and the bottom of the screen is by default 5 (shifting upward) and 8 (for a downward shift). You can alter these values under 'Zone Settings' (Upper/Lower Bounds). || Shifting from the default area to the secret area above/below the scroll limit can be tweaked by changing values for 'Upper Bounds'. The opposite is true for 'Lower Bounds' (shifting from default area to the secret area below. The increase/decrease of the scrollable area reduces/enlarges the necessary distance to the same extent that is needed to pull off the shifting. |||| If Mario goes back to the default area, the screen will quickly follow and it will be locked to the default area as usual (unless Mario goes above/below the scroll limit once again to reach the secret area)... |||| This option can be used to set up secret zones that can only be seen if Mario reaches a specific position. This technique was used in many older Mario games, e.g. Super Mario Land 3: Wario Land. So if you are located below the screen, nothing happens. Only when jumping over the area, the screen scrolls up so you can hide secret paths there as you like. Similarly, one can also hide secret paths under the screen.

value.title: Scroll Limit Shifting in Restricted Direction
value.comment: I don't know what practical purpose this has?
value.comment2: Determines how far the screen can scroll above/below the scroll limit (in blocks). Somewhat flawed if used together with 'Permeable Scroll Limit'. The position where the scrolling will begin does not differ from a scroll limit with shifting of 0. So it looks as if the screen is scrolling faster with increasing values ​​when Mario approaches it. Even higher values are canceled entirely and have no effect because the scrolling is no longer necessary when the end of the screen is too far above or below the end of the original screen border. Nevertheless, the screen jumps to the end of the scroll border when entering the default area again. Only if the bottom of the screen is too far beyond the original area (or vice versa), then the screen is already at the end of the scroll border, and no shifting of the screen is needed.

checkbox.title: Unknown Flag 6 (1)
checkbox.advancedcomment: Used in Retail: 02-01 A1, 05-24 A1, 06-02 A4.

value.title: Unknown Value 10
value.advancedcomment: From ASM: An independent effect differing from [Permeable Scroll Limit]. Details have not been researched.

value.title: Unknown Value 12
value.advancedcomment: From ASM: An independent effect differing from [Permeable Scroll Limit]. Details have not been researched.
