dependency.notes: The sprite snaps to the Path Node location. From Node-0 to Node-1, it must be a straight horizontal line, and it must be at least as long as the Snake Block itself. Straight lines and exact 45° angles are recommended, as after each Node, the Snake Block will navigate in a 1-by-1 zigzag until it reaches the height of the next Node before going straight.

value.title: Starting Node
value.comment: This determines the Node of the Path that the Snake Block will start moving from.

list.title: End Animation
list.comment: This determines what the Snake Block will do when it reaches the final Node of the Path. Values higher than 3 cause a crash.

sprite.name: Unused
sprite.notes: No assigned function, does nothing in-game.

sprite.name: Unused
sprite.notes: No assigned function, does nothing in-game.

sprite.name: Incomplete Sprite - 'En_Slip_Penguin'
sprite.notes: Does nothing.

sprite.name: Prickly Goomba
sprite.notes: A spiky brown ball that contains a normal Goomba, which will appear if it is shot with a Fireball. Fire Bro fireballs will also open it, but Fire Chomp fireballs will not.

sprite.name: Mushroom in a Bubble
sprite.notes: <font color="orange">This sprite is not recommended for use, and it WILL crash the game if used with invalid settings.</font>
sprite.advancednotes: This is capable of spawning both items and players inside of bubbles. Unfortunately it was not designed to be called on for stand-alone functions.

checkbox.title: Spawns Mushroom in a Bubble
checkbox.comment: When enabled, this will spawn a Mushroom floating in a bubble.

dualbox.comment: This determines how the floating bubble will appear.

list.title: Spawns Player in a Bubble
list.advancedcomment: Unfortunately, this doesn't work as cleanly as it needs to in order to be usable. If the right player doesn't exist when this loads, the game will crash. It could potentially respawn a dead player who has zero lives, or with the multiplayer bubbles deactivated, except that there is no way to only load the players you actually need. Thus, this function is completely and totally unreliable unless requiring all 4 players to play a particular level.

sprite.name: Screw Mushroom Platform with Bolt
sprite.notes: A mechanical biological hybrid of a mushroom platform that can magically control nearby similar non-Bolt platforms and various coins and blocks.

dependency.notes: This Bolt can only control specific sprites using specific modes.

value.title: Mushroom ID
value.comment: This pairs matching 'Mushroom' controlled objects to this platform's Bolt.
value.comment2: You cannot have more than one pair of Screw Platforms with the same Mushroom ID.

dualbox.comment: This determines which direction the platform will move when the Bolt is spun.

value.title: Distance
value.comment: This determines how far the platform will move when the Bolt is spun.

list.title: Movement Speed
list.comment: This determines the speed of the platform in the direction specified above. The 'returning' speed (0.2) is unaffected.

value.title: Unknown Value 7-8
value.advancedcomment: Used (1) in Retail: 01-05 A1.

sprite.name: Giant Floating Log
sprite.yoshinotes: Yoshi can't jump off of the log, and instead rides it to the bottom. Also, he can eat the whole thing.
sprite.notes: A very large log that will slowly try to dump the player into the liquid below.

dependency.notes: While this is not dependent on liquid in order to spawn, it should be noted that it only has collision along the top. While the player is along the top two blocks of the log, the log will generate spinning momentum and try to drop the player below it. Once the player passes those top two blocks, they will instantly fall no matter how fast the log is spinning.

sprite.name: (Unused) One Way Swinging Gate
sprite.notes: Another sprite ported from NSMB:DS, this gate will open when the player comes from a specific direction, rotate open 90°, and close shortly after the player has passed through it. It's somewhat buggy and not recommended for use in most levels, especially when multiple players are involved.

dualbox.comment: This will determine which way the gate will swing open.

list.title: Direction
list.comment: This determines which way the gate will open.
list.comment2: Values 2 and 3 are slightly buggy.

list.title: Direction
list.comment: This determines which way the gate will open.
list.comment2: Values 2 and 3 are slightly buggy.

list.title: Contains
list.comment: Unlisted values are Empty.

checkbox.title: Unknown Flag 5 (1)
checkbox.comment: Used in Retail: 06-05 A2. Possibly distance related.

sprite.name: Roulette Block
sprite.notes: A large roulette style block that will award either a Star, a 1-Up, a Mushroom, or a specific power-up item. It should be noted that it makes a moderate amount of noise when it's on screen.

list.title: Power-up
list.comment: This determines which power-up the block can provide.

sprite.name: Fire Chomp
sprite.notes: A stand-alone Fire Chomp that will float after the player, shooting the fireballs from its tail.

sprite.name: Basic Platform - Scale
sprite.notes: A variant of the basic platform that creates two platforms tied by a rope. This rope will 'break' if one platform is brought to the pulley for more than a moment, causing both platforms to fall.

value.title: Pulley Width
value.comment: This determines how far apart the two pulleys are from each other.
value.comment2: A value of 0 is not recommended for fairly obvious reasons.

value.title: Rope Length - Left Side
value.comment: This determines the starting length of rope attached to the left platform.

value.title: Rope Length - Right Side
value.comment: This determines the starting length of rope attached to the right platform.

list.title: Platform Width
list.comment: This determines the width of the two platforms.
list.advancedcomment: Values 13-15 are glitchy and do not work correctly in the game.

checkbox.title: Event Activated
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the platform will only appear if the Triggering Event ID is activated.

sprite.name: Special Exit Controller
sprite.notes: A special controller that will activate Entrance transitions when a player enters a specific area.
sprite.yoshinotes: Yoshi can eat the entire collision box of the special exit controller.

list.title: Width
list.comment: This determines the width of the area that the Special Exit Controller will check for the player inside of.

list.title: Height
list.comment: This determines the height of the area that the Special Exit Controller will check for the player inside of.

checkbox.title: Vine / Climbing Exit
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the Special Exit Controller will only activate if the player is also climbing while within the specified area.

checkbox.title: Exit, Stage Left
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the Special Exit Controller will eject the players from the current level.
checkbox.comment2: This will not complete the level. The player will be forced to walk left during the transition, and the Exit Transition will be overridden with an iris focused on the left side of the screen. There is no pipe sound for this transition.

list.title: Exit Transition
list.comment: This determines the transition animation used when the screen fades out.
list.comment2:
Wavy Transition - Bottom to Top: The screen will go black with a wavy line going from bottom to top.

Wavy Transition - Top to Bottom: The screen will go black with a wavy line going from top to bottom.

Wavy Transition - Top to Bottom (Delayed): Same as above, but the animation is not triggered immediately upon contact with the warp area, instead taking place after a small delay.

Black Iris and Pipe Sound: This option works just like a normal pipe exit, with a black circle enclosing the triggering player's position. At the same time, the sound effect that plays when entering a normal pipe is also played.

value.title: Entrance ID
value.comment: This determines the Entrance ID that the Special Exit Controller links to. When triggered, the player will go to the Destination of the linked Entrance.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: When the Triggering Event is 0, or is currently activated, the Special Exit Controller will also be active. If the Triggering Event is set and the Event is not activated, the Special Exit Controller will not function even when the player is inside it.

sprite.name: Cheep-Chomp
sprite.notes: A rather large Cheep enemy that is capable of swallowing the player whole, killing them instantly regardless of their power-up state. Star excluded, of course.

value.title: Location ID
value.comment: The Cheep Cheep will spawn from below the camera line, attacking the player only while they are within this location.

sprite.name: Event Triggered Door
sprite.notes: A hidden door that can have an Entrance placed on it. It will only appear when the Triggering Event ID is activated.
sprite.advancednotes: The door can also be paired with a Rotation Controller, but the results are moderately glitchy with many combinations not functioning and several restrictions on getting them to work as actual doors.

list.title: Orientation
list.comment: This determines which direction the door will be facing.
list.comment2: A door can only be entered if it is upright. As decoration, this is fine. Actually making it properly associate its corresponding Entrance is either impossible or very functionally strange.

checkbox.title: Rotation Controlled (Buggy)
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the door will only function when paired with a Rotation ID.
checkbox.advancedcomment: 'Function' is perhaps misleading. There are only a few ways you can successfully utilize a Rotation Controller door. For starters, you can only enter the door while it is almost fully upright. There is also a peculiarity with how the Entrance is placed. The most reliable way to use a Rotation Controlled Door is to place it with an already activated Spinning controller that returns to its original position when deactivated.

value.title: Rotation ID
value.comment: This pairs the Door to a matching rotation controller.

sprite.name: Incomplete Sprite - 'En_TarzanRope'
sprite.notes: Does nothing.

sprite.name: Incomplete Sprite - 'Mask'
sprite.notes: Does nothing. "Mask" Original sprite used to create the see-through effect of Layer 0 tiles. The effect was meant to activate once the selected character enters Layer 0 tiles, but this actor is spawned automatically by the game with all 8 options enabled.

list.title: Character
list.comment: The Yoshi's are numbered by their spawn order.

sprite.name: Ambush - Toad Balloon
sprite.notes: Collecting 8 of these spawns a Toad House Chest. Any additional Toad Balloons are treated as the 8th Balloon. Requires an Ambush Level Controller for the balloons to spawn and function.

dependency.notes: The [454] Ambush Controller will allow the Toad Balloons to spawn. When 8 Toad Balloons have been collected, (most) enemies will be killed, and any [203] Item Chests set to spawn from Ambush Controllers will spawn.

checkbox.title: Place Behind Other Sprites
checkbox.comment: When enabled, this changes the relative Z-Order of the Toad Balloon placing it further behind other sprites.

sprite.name: Collision Switcher - Mini-Mario Only
sprite.notes: This controller will switch the active collision layer from Layer 1 to Layer 2 and vice versa, but only for players with the Mini-Mushroom power-up. See Retail W1-3 A1 for a usage example.

list.title: Switch to Layer 2 (Behind)
list.comment: This determines the direction the player must be traveling from in order to activate the switch to Layer 2, the background layer.

list.title: Switch to Layer 1 (Normal)
list.comment: This determines the direction the player must be traveling from in order to activate the switch to Layer 1, the normal plane of existence.

sprite.name: Player Block
sprite.notes: A player hitting this block will be granted tilt control of all Line Controlled Player-Block Platforms in the zone.

dependency.notes: The only sprite that is associated with the Player Block is the [333] Line Controlled Player-Block Platform.

sprite.name: Midway Flag
sprite.notes: A flag that when touched by the player will mark their progress in the level and respawn them at this location when re-entering the level.

value.title: Entrance ID
value.comment: This determines which Entrance the level will load the player into when they respawn.

dualbox.comment: This determines which direction the players will face when they respawn.
Once activated, the 1st checkpoint can not be deactivated by the 2nd checkpoint, and vise-versa.

sprite.name: Larry Koopa
sprite.yoshinotes: Yoshi can only be hurt while the boss is inside its shell and spinning around. Additionally, Yoshi will despawn the boss entirely if he ground pounds it, softlocking the game.

dependency.notes: Requires the Tower Boss Controller to start moving on his own and complete the level after he's beat. Otherwise, he will start moving when damaged.

sprite.name: (Unused) Tilt Controlled Girder
sprite.notes: <font color="red">It is not recommended for use due to a collision box not completely matching the model.</font> Just use [51] instead.
sprite.advancednotes: This uses the same 3D model as the used Tilt Lift, but this one has collisions that extend two blocks farther on the right side.

sprite.name: Tile God Event
sprite.notes: The Tile God can Create / Change / Destroy tiles within a specified area when an Event is activated.

dependency.notes: The Tile God sprite can be placed no more than one block outside of the Zone it is being activated in for it to function.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: When this Event ID is activated, the tiles affected by the Tile God's area will be created or destroyed, depending on the Mode.

value.title: Width
value.comment: This determines the width of the area that is affected.

value.title: Height
value.comment: This determines the height of the area that is affected.

dualbox.comment: This determines how the Tile God will act when the Triggering Event is activated.
dualbox.comment2: When creating, the Tile God will place these tiles on top of existing tiles instead of replacing them.

dualbox.comment: This determines how the Tile God will act when the Triggering Event is deactivated
dualbox.comment2: When set to Reverse, previously created tiles will be destroyed, and locations where tiles were destroyed will be filled by the creation settings of the Tile God.

checkbox.title: Disable Effects
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the visual effect for Tile Creation/Destruction will be removed.

checkbox.title: Disable Sounds
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the sound effect for Tile Creation/Destruction will be removed.

list.title: Pattern
list.comment: This determines the fill pattern for the Tile God's selected area.
list.comment2: A checkered pattern and reverse checked pattern overlapping will create the same effect as a regular fill. This is sometimes useful for its visual effect.

list.title: Tile
list.comment: This determines what terrain tile will appear at the Tile God's selected area

sprite.name: Larry Koopa - Castle Boss
sprite.yoshinotes: Yoshi can only be hurt while the boss is inside its shell and spinning around. Additionally, Yoshi will despawn the boss entirely if he ground pounds it, softlocking the game.
sprite.notes: The boss initially has no collision. From rest, the platform moves 3 tiles up and 1 tile down. The white square indicates the placement for the Castle Boss controller. Mario spawns at Entrance 3 after the battle.

dependency.notes: For more help setting up the boss room, see the zone from the original game.

sprite.name: Urchin
sprite.notes: A small spiky ball enemy typically used in Water. Water is not required, however, for it to load and function.

value.title: Movement Distance (*2)
value.comment: This determines how far the Urchin will move, if at all. Multiply this value by 2.

dualbox.comment: This determines which direction the Urchin will move. The starting position from their movement is in the center, not at one of the two edges.
This determines which direction the Urchin will move first. The starting position from their movement is in the center, not at one of the two edges.
This determines which direction the Urchin will move first. The starting position from their movement is in the center, not at one of the two edges.

sprite.name: Mega Urchin
sprite.notes: A large spiky ball enemy typically used in Water. Water is not required, however, for it to load and function.

value.title: Movement Distance (x2)
value.comment: This determines how far the Urchin will move, if at all. Multiply this value by 2.

dualbox.comment: This determines which direction the Urchin will move.
This determines which direction the Urchin will move first.
This determines which direction the Urchin will move first.

sprite.name: Huckit Crab
sprite.notes: A crab enemy that will throw projectiles at the player while occasionally jumping in the air.

list.title: Shooting Speed
list.comment: This determines the speed of the projectile that the Huckit Crab will huck.
list.comment2: Many values are excluded due to abnormal or glitchy behavior.

list.title: Advanced / Glitchy Shooting Options
list.comment: A full list of the Shooting Speed options including duplicates and those not suggested for use.
list.advancedcomment: Many values will cause the Huckit Crab to toss his projectile behind him. One option will also cause him to face the wrong direction, as well.

dependency.notes: Requires non-location non-moving Water in order to appear and function.

list.title: Swim Distance
list.comment: This determines how far the Fishbones will swim before turning around.

list.title: Start Direction
list.comment: This determines the direction the Fishbones will start swimming in.
list.comment2: Swims In Place: The Fishbones will look into the camera, then (from this position) swim one block to the left. If Mario is close while the Fish Bone is swimming left, it will chase Mario while still facing the camera.

value.title: Unknown Value 10
value.comment: ASM shows Nybble 10 might affect something. May relate to Swims In Place.

sprite.name: Clampy
sprite.notes: A clam with tantalizing items inside that will hurt the player if it closes while they are in inside of it.

dependency.notes: Clampies need to be placed inside of a grid space. Otherwise they will not appear during gameplay.

checkbox.title: Falls
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the Clampy will be affected by gravity and environmental effects.

list.title: Contains
list.comment: This determines what item is inside the Clampy.
list.advancedcomment: Values 5 and higher crash the game upon level load.

checkbox.title: Upside-Down P-Switch/Star-Coin Z-Order
checkbox.comment: This will affect the secondary trait of the P-Switch or Star Coin.
checkbox.advancedcomment: These are both incredibly useless options. An Upside-Down P-Switch cannot be pressed, and the Z-Order puts the Star Coin behind the Clampy.

sprite.name: Giant Goomba
sprite.notes: A larger version of the Goomba that splits into two regular Goombas when stepped on.

sprite.name: Mega Goomba
sprite.notes: An even larger version of the Goomba that splits into two Giant Goombas when stepped on.

sprite.name: Micro Goomba
sprite.notes: A very small Goomba that clings to the player until they spin jump to shake them off.

sprite.name: Icicle
sprite.notes: A small hanging icicle that does not fall but can still hurt the player if they touch it. When touched by [388] Barrel, the Barrel breaks. Note that this is unlike [265] Falling Icicle, where the Falling Icicle breaks instead of the Barrel.

list.title: Size
list.comment2: Higher values cause crashes.

dependency.notes: Players shot out of the cannon will pass through all terrain, leave the Zone, and softlock without the controller.

sprite.name: Chest
sprite.notes: A chest affected by gravity that will award some type of inventory item to the player. Note that opening a chest will complete the level with the standard exit. Keep in mind that if you allow the player to leave the vicinity of the chest before it exits the player from the level, they will be able to open it again for another item, so do not allow the player to do this.

dependency.notes: Requires ONE of these two sprites in order to not cause the game to crash. Which one depends on how the chest is being used. If you're using it as part of an Ambush level, [454] is required. If you're using it without the Ambush arrangement, [432] is required to be placed somewhere in the level, even if it's outside of the active Zones.

checkbox.title: Unknown Flag 5 (1)
checkbox.comment: No visible change. Used in the Ambushes of World 6.

checkbox.title: Unknown Flag 9 (1)
checkbox.comment: No visible change. Checked in all ambushes except those in Worlds 1 and 2.

list.title: Chest Type
list.comment: Determines the behavior and contents of the chest.

list.title: Mushroom Reward Amount
list.comment: Determines the number of Mushrooms the chest spawns. Specifying more than 5 Mushrooms can cause glitchy visual behavior, but it still works.

list.title: Contains
list.comment: Determines the item in the chest. This only works with the Default Chest Type, as the other settings would just spawn Mushrooms.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: The chest will only appear when the Triggering Event is 0 or is activated. It will not disappear if the Event is deactivated.

sprite.name: Rolling Object Spawner
sprite.notes: A spawner that will create loose Spiked Balls or Rolling Barrels.

dualbox.comment: This determines which object the spawner will create.

value.title: Deactivation Event ID
value.comment: While this Event ID is triggered, the spawner will not spawn any Spiked Balls.

list.title: Speed
list.comment: This determines the speed of the spawned spike ball.
list.comment2: Stopped spike balls will still be affected by the terrain they are resting on. This corresponds to nybble 12 on sprite [63].

list.title: Direction
list.comment: This determines the direction in which the spawned objects will roll in.
list.comment2: Value 3 is identical to value 2. Higher values than 3 for the Rolling Barrels cause an out-of-bounds read, which probably leads to unexpected results.

value.title: Maximum Number of Objects
value.comment: If there are more than this number of rolling objects loaded, the spawner will not spawn any new ones. Note that this includes all instances of the rolling object, even if they were not spawned by this spawner.
value.comment2: If set to 0, it will continuously spawn objects.

value.title: Delay
value.comment: This is the delay between consecutive objects. The unit is half a second (30 frames), with a default of 3 seconds (180 frames). Note that these are real seconds, not in-game timer ticks
value.comment2: Note that this is the number of frames when there are no(?) objects of the specified type loaded.

sprite.name: Water Ball
sprite.notes: A floating ball of water that can move around and synchronize its movement with Coins.

dependency.notes: Water Balls require that [317] Enables Bubbles be placed in every Zone containing a Water Ball.

value.title: Water Ball ID
value.comment: This pairs matching 'Water Ball' controlled objects to this controller.

list.title: Size
list.comment: This determines the size and shape of the Water Ball.

dualbox.comment: This determines which direction the Water Ball will drift.
This determines which initial direction the Water Ball will drift.
This determines which initial direction the Water Ball will drift.

value.title: Distance Moved
value.comment: This determines the distance the Water Ball will drift in one direction before returning.

sprite.name: Zoom Controller
sprite.notes: A controller that creates an 'area' where the zoom of the camera changes when a player enters it.

value.title: Affected Height
value.comment: This determines the height of the affected area.

value.title: Affected Width
value.comment: This determines the width of the affected area.

list.title: Screen's Zoomed Height
list.comment: This determines what the new screen height will be while a player is within the controller's area.
list.comment2:
*: The height is determined by the normal Zoom Level; the value within the brackets will be used if Zone Bias is enabled.

**: When a player enters the affected area, the height will 'immediately be set to 10 blocks shorter than the final height and then grows to the correct size, and when the players leave the affected area this process is reversed.'

checkbox.title: First Flag
checkbox.comment: This sets the 'first flag' on the zoomed-in effect. Its precise effects are unknown.

list.title: Number of players
list.comment: The Zoom Controller will be in effect when the right number of people are playing and at least one player is in the specified area.

sprite.notes: Your most basic, most flexible, standard Question Block. When spawning power-ups, it will spawn enough for every player! Such a generous block~

list.comment: This determines which type of movement the Block will be assigned.
list.comment2: Movement Types 2, and 9+ are unused or otherwise unknown. Movement Type 3 and Type 8 only function with Coins. If you want to experiment with unknown Types, you'll need to modify the Raw Data.

value.comment: If pairing the ?-Block with Sprite 159, match the Path Movement ID to enable Path controlled movement.

value.title: Two Way Line ID
value.comment: If pairing the ?-Block with sprite 260, match the Two Way Line ID to enable Two Way synchronized movement.

value.title: Set to Zero
value.comment: If pairing the ?-Block with sprite 474, no further action is needed to create Dancing synchronized movement.

value.title: Set to Zero
value.comment: If pairing the ?-Block with sprite 474, no further action is needed to create Dancing synchronized movement.

value.title: Mushroom ID
value.comment: If pairing the ?-Block with sprite 172, match the Mushroom ID to enable Mushroom Bolt controlled movement. It will be paired to the platform with the Bolt.

value.title: Mushroom ID
value.comment: If pairing the ?-Block with sprite 382, match the Mushroom ID to enable Mushroom Bolt controlled movement. It will be paired to the platform without the Bolt.

list.title: Block Contains
list.comment: This determines what item the block contains.
list.comment2: This block will release as many items as there are players.

checkbox.title: Place Behind Other Sprites
checkbox.comment: When enabled, this changes the relative Z-order of the ?-Block placing it further behind other sprites.
checkbox.comment2: This will place the ?-Block behind even Chainlink Fence and Layer 1 terrain.

checkbox.title: Follows Lines

sprite.name: Incomplete Sprite - 'Tarzan_Rope'
sprite.notes: Does nothing.

sprite.name: Boss Controller - Bowser Jr. (1st Battle)
sprite.notes: This controls the mechanics for the first Bowser Jr. Boss Fight in World 4. It spawns the backgrounds BgA_5602 and BgB_5302, and will overlap any other backgrounds set in the zone. The white square indicates the placement for the Airship Boss Cutscene controller.

dependency.notes: Specific room settings are likely required. Please reference the original Retail level, 04-38 A1.

sprite.name: Rolling Hill
sprite.notes: A rotating circle that has the same general appearance as various tilesets.

dependency.notes: The underside of a Rolling Hill does NOT have collision. Do not place a Rolling Hill in any situation where the player would have contact with the bottom 50% of the hill.

list.title: Style / Size
list.comment: This determines the style and size of the Rolling Hill.

value.title: Custom Size
value.comment: This determines the size of the Rolling Hill when using Flexible Size

value.title: Speed
value.comment: This determines the rotation speed of the Rolling Hill. A value of 5 matches Mario's running speed, so use of higher values isn't recommended.

dualbox.comment: This determines which direction the Rolling Hill rolls.

value.title: Z-Order
value.comment: This determines the relative Z-Order placement of the Rolling Hill when compared to other Rolling Hills.
value.comment2: If you have multiple Rolling Hills overlapping each other, you must use this setting to prevent graphical glitches. Rolling Hills with a higher Z-Order number will show behind those with a lower number.

value.title: Hill ID
value.comment: This pairs matching Rolling Hill Coins to this hill.

sprite.name: Incomplete Sprite - 'Branch'
sprite.notes: Does nothing.

sprite.name: Path Controlled Ghost House Platform
sprite.notes: A wide path controlled platform that will trigger a spooky sound when it is quickly descending.

dependency.notes: This platform will only function when paired with a Use Paths movement controller.

value.title: Path Movement ID
value.comment: This pairs the platform to a matching Use Paths controller.

value.title: Higher Pitched Falling Sound
value.comment: This determines something involving the sound that is heard when the platform is falling quickly.
value.comment2: The Path's Speed must be at least 5.0 for this sound to be heard. It's assumed that a higher value will skip further into the music track that plays when the platform is quickly dropping. Retail uses 1 and 5.

checkbox.title: Unknown Flag 10 (4)
checkbox.comment: For whatever reason, this is always checked in Retail levels.

sprite.name: Bullet Bill Spawn Area
sprite.notes: Assigns a spawn area where waves of Bullet Bills will continue to be fired at the player while they are inside it.

value.title: Location ID
value.comment: Groups of Bullet Bills are fired across the screen only while a player is in this location.

list.title: Number of Bullet Bills
list.comment: This determines how many Bullet Bills will be fired during each wave.
list.comment2: Each Bullet Bill will have two blocks of empty space between it and the next one.

list.title: Spacing Between Groups
list.comment: This setting seems to be false, unless assuming only this setting is adjusted and the player is not moving. In which case, maybe it will tweak the randomness to alternate between low and high.
list.advancedcomment: When used with "Number per Group" this controls the spacing between two groups (horizontally).

value.title: Alignment
value.comment: This seems like it affects how much randomness there is in where the bullet bill can spawn within the zone.
value.advancedcomment: (S) 0-15. Has to do with vertical alignment. Needs further info.

value.title: Y (Height) Offset
value.comment: Does this define the 'center' of the area the bullet bills spawn or does this allow for the game to track the location when Mario is flying in the air above the camera? What is the point of this?
value.advancedcomment: (S) 0-15 Used with bottom alignment. Higher values raise height of spawn area.

sprite.name: Poisoned Water
sprite.notes:
Place this in the level to generate poisonous water. There are many different ways to use Poisoned Water.

Location Poisoned Water: If you assign a Location ID, you can cause poisonous water to appear only within the chosen Location instead of across the entire stage.

Moving Poisoned Water: You can also create poisonous water that rises and/or falls. This gets a little complicated, so be sure to read the related settings.

Poison Water Crest's Maximum Length: The crest of Poison Water will stop drawing past 8192 pixels (512 blocks). You can avoid this by making multiple instances of Location Poisoned Water. Make sure that the widths of the locations are no greater than 8192, and that they are multiples of 16.

dependency.notes: When using Moving Poisoned Water, the Poisoned Water becomes loaded across the entire Area instead of just the active Zone. Please build your levels with this in mind. Additionally, do not use more than one Moving Poisoned Water in the same Area as only the top (highest Y-Axis) one will take effect. Unlike with Moving Water you cannot use Moving Poisoned Water in multiple Zones within the same area, unless you place them at the same Y-Axis. Also, be sure to reset your Sprite Settings if you switch between different setting groups of Moving Poisoned Water or Location Poisoned Water to prevent unusual bugs and behavior.

list.title: Moving Poisoned Water - Rising Speed
list.comment: This determines the speed at which the Poisoned Water will rise, or rise and fall.

list.title: Moving Poisoned Water - Falling Speed
list.comment: This determines the speed at which the Poisoned Water will fall.

list.title: I really wouldn't do that if I were you...
list.comment: Right now, you've selected [Extremely Buggy]. You've made a terrible mistake somewhere and have combined the wrong settings.
list.comment2: Please don't try to set Distance or Delays while using Falling Poisoned Water. You will not like the results. Please trust me.
list.advancedcomment: Oh, so you turned on Advanced, did you? You think you're so smart... Well fine, I'll share the limited documentation we have on why you shouldn't use these settings: Falling Poisoned Water works in a peculiar way. When the appropriate event has not been activated, or there is no corresponding event, [Never ON] then the water surface will appear [Distance] blocks higher. The water will then sink this many blocks, respecting any delays. After waiting for the delay at the bottom, the water surface will not rise again. Not exactly. Instead, it will 'skip' the rising part and 'jump' to immediately to the top. Additionally, using this with events will cause the water to rise, instead of falling. [ON] But the starting point is the same higher distance. The difference is that the water rises continuously as long as the event is enabled. [Endless Rising] If it is disabled, [OFF after ON] the water surface will 'jump' back to where it started and remain there until the event is re-enabled. [Why bother?] Additionally, 1-5 on Movement Speed values have some additional odd glitchiness. Supposedly. So please, stop trying to combine settings like this. Or your level will suck.

dualbox.comment: This determines which direction the Poisoned Water will move.
This determines which direction the Poisoned Water will move while the Triggering Event is activated.
The Poisoned Water will automatically rise and fall in accordance with the set delays.

dualbox.title1: [???] Rises Distance while On, Falls when Off
dualbox.comment: The Poisoned Water will rise the Distance value once activated, and stay at the top until the Triggering Event is deactivated. If the Triggering Event is deactivated before it rises the full distance, it will finish rising, then immediately start to fall.
dualbox.comment2: This option only applies if Delay values are both set to 0, Distance is set, and Triggering ID is set. Do not use [Extremely Buggy]. No really, don't. It won't help you any.

dualbox.title1: [???] Rising and Falling while On, Glitch-Returns when Off
dualbox.comment: The Poisoned Water will rise and fall in accordance with the set delays while the Triggering Event is activated.
dualbox.comment2: When the Triggering Event is deactivated, the Poisoned Water will immediately return to its starting position in a glitchy manner. It is highly recommended to not cause this to happen in your level design. Use Event Chainers with Delays or the Event Looper to get this type of timing instead.

value.title: Moving Poisoned Water - Distance
value.comment: This determines how many blocks the Poisoned Water will move.
value.comment2: Setting this will drastically change the function of Moving Poisoned Water. Please keep this in mind.

value.title: I wouldn't do that if I were you...
value.comment: This determines how many blocks the Poisoned Water will move. Normally. But you are a bad person and are trying to set combinations of options that are known not to work. So stop right there and either change this back to zero, or select the option to the left of where it says [Extremely Buggy].

value.title: Moving Poisoned Water - Delay at Top
value.comment: This determines the delay when the Poisoned Water has finished rising.

value.title: Moving Poisoned Water - Delay at Bottom
value.comment: This determines the delay when the Poisoned Water has returned to its starting position.
value.comment2: The initial delay only can be set by using event-controlled Poisoned Water. Utilize Event Chainers to fake the delay settings if you need to set an initial delay.

value.title: Moving Poisoned Water - Triggering Event ID
value.comment: The Moving Poisoned Water mode will be triggered when this Event is activated.

value.title: Location Poisoned Water - Location ID
value.comment: Match with a Location ID to set a specific area in which to display Poisoned Water.
value.comment2: Note that some sprites only work correctly in Non-Location Poisoned Water.
value.advancedcomment: Location Poisoned Water only works properly with Location IDs 0-127. Location IDs 128-255 will cause the Poisoned Water to constantly move up and down slightly. It's unknown if a use can be found for this, so it remains documented here in the Advanced Comment.

checkbox.title: Location Poisoned Water - Flat Top
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the animated crest effect on the top portion of the Poisoned Water is removed. This creates a 'square' look.
checkbox.comment2: It's recommended to only use this when the Poisoned Water is touching a straight ceiling.

sprite.name: Fire Chomp Spawn Area
sprite.notes: Assigns a spawn area where Fire Chomps will continue to respawn while the player is inside it. Fire Chomps will float after the player shooting the fireballs from its tail, and explode when they run out of ammo.

value.title: Location ID
value.comment: Fire Chomps respawn and chase the player only while a player is in this location.

value.title: Spawn Delay
value.comment: This determines the amount of time the game will wait before spawning another Fire Chomp.

checkbox.title: Unknown Flag 10 (1)
checkbox.advancedcomment: Used in Retail: 02-06 A1

sprite.name: (Unused) Invisible Block
sprite.notes: Creates an invisible block. When hit, it will release a coin and move one tile up. The settings seem to be hardcoded, making this sprite almost fully unusable.

value.title: Unknown Value 9
value.advancedcomment: Setting this and nybble 11 to something nonzero might influence the collision of the block.

value.title: Unknown Value 11
value.advancedcomment: Setting this and nybble 9 to something nonzero might influence the collision of the block.

value.title: Unknown Value 8
value.advancedcomment: Does nothing.

value.title: Unknown Value 10
value.advancedcomment: Does nothing.

value.title: Unknown Value 12
value.advancedcomment: Does nothing.

sprite.name: Stretching Line Block
sprite.notes: A platform made up of orange or other-colored blocks that shrinks and expands while moving up and down.

dependency.notes: This platform can be paired with [312] Stretching Line Block Controller in order to synchronize movement across multiple platforms.

value.title: Width - Top
value.comment: This determines the width of the platform when it is in its top position.

value.title: Width - Bottom
value.comment: This determines the width of the platform when it is in its bottom position.

dualbox.comment: This determines the initial direction the platform will move.

value.title: Stretch ID
value.comment: This pairs the platform to a matching controller for movement synchronization.

value.title: Movement Distance
value.comment: This determines the distance between the top and bottom states of the platform.
value.comment2: The speed is constant and not based on how large the distance is, so larger distances will take longer to travel. Additionally, because the change in the number of blocks is accomplished in the same time period of time that it takes the Stretching Line Block to travel up or down, if the movement distance is 0 then the platform will grow or shrink immediately.

sprite.name: Cheep Cheep Spawn Area - Swimming
sprite.notes: Assigns a spawn area where Cheep Cheep will continue to swim across the screen from the left towards the player while they are inside it.

dependency.notes: You will need Water in order for this spawn area to function, and if using Deep Cheeps, it must be non-location, non-moving Water.

dualbox.comment: This determines what type of Cheep will be spawned.
dualbox.comment2: Cheep Cheeps will swim straight left, while Deep Cheeps will chase the player slightly.

dualbox.comment: This determines how the Cheep Cheeps will move.
dualbox.comment2: This only affects Cheep Cheeps. Wavy Line Cheep Cheeps will drift up and down slightly.

checkbox.title: Higher Spawn Rate
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the 'Cheeps will spawn more often.

checkbox.title: Different Spawn Style
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the way the 'Cheeps are spawned by this spawn area will differ.

value.title: Location ID
value.comment: The above type of fish will spawn from from the left side of the screen, swimming after the player only while they are within this location.

sprite.name: Invisible Block
sprite.notes: Your most sneaky, most annoying, hidden transparent Invisible Block. When spawning power-ups, it will spawn only one, no matter how many players! Such a rude block~
sprite.advancednotes: The tileset-based Invisible Blocks can be destroyed by sprites like Bob-ombs. Sprite-based Invisible Blocks however cannot be destroyed.

list.comment2:
Movement Types 2, and 9+ are unused or otherwise unknown.

value.title: Two Way Line ID
value.comment: If pairing the Invisible Block with sprite 260, match the Two Way Line ID to enable Two Way synchronized movement.

value.title: Set to Zero
value.comment: If pairing the Invisible Block with sprite 474, no further action is needed to create Dancing synchronized movement.

value.title: Set to Zero
value.comment: If pairing the Invisible Block with sprite 474, no further action is needed to create Dancing synchronized movement.

value.comment: If pairing the Invisible Block with sprite 172, match the Mushroom ID to enable Mushroom Bolt controlled movement. It will be paired to the platform with the Bolt.

value.title: Mushroom ID
value.comment: If pairing the Invisible Block with sprite 382, match the Mushroom ID to enable Mushroom Bolt controlled movement. It will be paired to the platform without the Bolt.

list.title: Block Contains
list.comment: This determines what item the block contains.
list.comment2: This block will only release one power-up item. If the invisible block has 10 coins, it will stay in the used block graphic the entire time. Additionally, it won't release the extra few coins if the block is hit multiple times successfully.

checkbox.title: Place Behind Other Sprites
checkbox.comment: When enabled, this changes the relative Z-Order of the Invisible Block placing it further behind other sprites.
checkbox.comment2: This will place the Invisible Block behind even Chainlink Fence and Layer 1 terrain.

dualbox.comment: This determines which direction the Invisible Block will move based on the Line that it is connected to.

sprite.name: (Unused) Conveyor Belt Spike
sprite.notes: A loose spike that when placed on a conveyor belt, will rotate around with the belt. It can only move in one direction (clockwise) and one speed. It does not load Zone-wide so it will not sync across multiple sections of a single Zone.

sprite.name: Checkered Spring Block
sprite.notes: A block with a spring-like effect that allows the player to jump on it and bounce off of it in order to jump higher.

checkbox.title: Alternate Color Pattern
checkbox.comment: When enabled, it will use the alternate color.

sprite.name: Jumbo Ray
sprite.notes: A large manta ray enemy that the player can stand on. It cannot hurt the player and instead functions similarly to a platform.

dependency.notes: In order for the Jumbo Ray to respawn, you must include a Jumbo Ray Respawner. This sprite's vertical placement is irrelevant - the Jumbo Ray will always spawn from the bottom of the Zone. The sprite still needs to be placed within the Zone, however. For cleanliness sake, you should make the Zone a bit taller and use a Scroll Limiter pair along the bottom in order to hide the lower part of the zone.

value.title: Initial Delay?
value.comment: Definitely not measured in Mario seconds.

dualbox.comment: This determines the direction the Jumbo Ray will travel across the screen.

value.title: Altitude (Flight Route)
value.comment: This determines how high the Jumbo Ray will fly up from the bottom of the screen.
value.comment2: More research is required on the exact details of each number, but Retail levels use 1 and 2 with 2 being higher, while Newer also uses 0 which also seems to be fairly high.

value.title: Ray ID
value.comment: This determines which Jumbo Ray Respawner will influence the respawn of this Jumbo Ray.

sprite.name: Floating Coin
sprite.notes: A standard Coin that floats on the surface of the Zone's non-Location Water, Poisoned Water, or Lava.

dependency.notes: Place this coin at the the horizontal position you want it to load, and it will spawn floating at the surface line of the body of liquid. It only works with non-Location liquids, and it does work with Moving liquids.

sprite.name: (Unused) Water Ball
sprite.notes: Appears to be identical to [205] Water Ball, but it has an internal name ending in _Regular. Just use [205] instead.

dependency.notes: Water Balls require that [317] Enables Bubbles be placed in every Zone containing a Water Ball.

value.title: Water Ball ID
value.comment: This pairs matching 'Water Ball' controlled objects to this controller.

list.title: Size
list.comment: This determines the size and shape of the Water Ball.

dualbox.comment: This determines which direction the Water Ball will drift.
This determines which initial direction the Water Ball will drift.
This determines which initial direction the Water Ball will drift.

value.title: Distance Moved
value.comment: This determines the distance the Water Ball will drift in one direction before returning.

sprite.name: Pipe Cannon
sprite.notes: An enterable pipe that will shoot the player upwards allowing them to reach new heights.
sprite.advancednotes: Pipe Cannons use the green pipe tile from Pa0.

list.title: Firing Direction
list.comment: This determines which direction the Pipe Cannon will launch the player.

sprite.name: Stretching Mushroom Platform
sprite.notes: A stretching platform that looks like a mushroom with naturally synchronized timing.

dualbox.comment: This determines the width of the Mushroom Platform when expanded.
This determines the initial state of the Mushroom Platform.

list.title: Height of Stem
list.comment: This determines the height of the decorative mushroom stem.

sprite.name: Sand Pillar
sprite.notes: A sand pillar that pushes the player upwards and can be stood on.

sprite.name: Bramball
sprite.notes: A long-legged enemy with a ball for a body that will flip itself around as it traverses terrain with proper spacing. Rumor has it that if it is struck from below with a Pipe Cannon, a large amount of coins will appear.

dependency.notes: For a Bramball to want to move, he must have solid terrain exactly 4 blocks from his legs.

dualbox.comment: This determines how quickly the Bramball will traverse platforms.

list.title: Initial Movement
list.comment: This determines which direction the Bramball will attempt to move first.

sprite.name: Wiggling Mushroom Platform
sprite.notes: A mushroom platform that can tilt back and forth.

dependency.notes: Wiggling Mushroom Platforms may be paired with [313] Wiggling Mushroom Controller to enable synchronized movement across a Zone.

dualbox.comment: This determines whether or not the platform extends and contracts.

value.title: Wiggling Mushroom ID
value.comment: This pairs the platform to a matching Wiggling Mushroom Controller for synchronized movement. If an ID is set, that ID will control and override all matching Wiggle Speeds.

value.title: Tilt Distance
value.comment: This determines how much the platform will tilt. A value of 1 or 2 is recommended.

dualbox.comment: This determines the length of the stem when the platform is contracted.

sprite.name: Mecha-Koopa
sprite.notes: A mechanical wind-up Koopa that can be picked up after being stomped on and carried around like a shell.

sprite.name: Lighting - Bulber
sprite.notes: An underwater fish that will light up the area nearby him if the lights are off.

dependency.notes: Bulbers do not require non-location water in order to spawn.

checkbox.title: Half Movement Speed
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the Bulber will move at half of its normal speed.

value.title: Distance
value.comment: This determines how far to each side of its spawn that the Bulber will move before turning around.

sprite.name: Effect - Cloud Area
sprite.notes: This adds decorative patches of cloud cover with different properties. Most modes required a Location ID, but some do not.

list.title: Cloud Type
list.comment: This determines which type of cloud will be spawned. See the extra comment for details.
list.comment2:
Normal: A light patch of clouds spawns in the Location ID. It is denser than [446].
Dense: A dense patch of clouds spawns in the Location ID.
Death Clouds: - A dense patch of purple clouds that will instantly kill the player spawns in the Location ID. They can be cleared away with spin jumps.
Drifting Death Clouds: A dense patch of purple clouds that spawns around a specific Location ID, that proceeds to drifts to the right across the entire stage. It cannot be cleared away with a spin jump like other Death Clouds, and it will generate a rumbling sound effect when the player is close to it. (A Location ID may not actually be required.)
Falling Clouds: Clouds fall in the background across the entire stage.
list.advancedcomment:
1, 3: Used by Foo and cannot be placed.
6, 9-15: No clouds spawn.

value.title: Location ID
value.comment: This determines the location in which the cloud effect will appear.

sprite.name: Jumbo Ray Respawner
sprite.notes: A controller that will respawn or otherwise spawn additional Jumbo Rays.

dependency.notes: The Jumbo Ray Respawner will spawn additional Jumbo Rays identical to those that are manually placed and share a matching Ray ID. This sprite's placement is irrelevant, but the sprite still needs to be placed within the Zone.

value.title: Ray ID
value.comment: This determines which Jumbo Rays will be respawned by this controller.

value.title: Spawn Delay (Set Above 0!)
value.comment: This determines how soon after the launch of the initial Jumbo Ray that another one will be spawned.
value.comment2: A value of 1 is equal to about the width of one Jumbo Ray. <font color="red">Do not use a value of 0 or the game will crash.</font>

value.title: Unknown Value 9
value.advancedcomment: Used in Retail: 05-05 A1, 0+F

sprite.name: Group Controller
sprite.notes: This controller will cause linked sprites to spawn at the same time, allowing for consistent synchronized movement. There are no sprites that require this to function.

sprite.name: Blue P-Switch Coin
sprite.notes: A blue coin that will only appear while the effects of a P-Switch are active.

dependency.notes: Players like to be congratulated for their accomplishments. You should pair each Blue Coin together with a Collection Controller so that when all Blue Coins are collected, the player is awarded with a hearty round of applause.

checkbox.title: Place Behind Other Sprites
checkbox.comment: When enabled, this changes the relative Z-Order of the Blue Coin placing it further behind other sprites.

value.title: Collection ID
value.comment: Links this Coin to 459

sprite.name: Incomplete Sprite - 'Mist_Intermittent'
sprite.notes: Does nothing.

sprite.name: Big Wiggler
sprite.notes: A very large Wiggler that could not care less what you do to it, so you can safely ride on its back.

checkbox.title: Moves Slightly Faster
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the Wiggler will move slightly faster than normal.

sprite.name: (Unused) Big Wiggler Spawner
sprite.notes: <font color="red">Currently non-functioning.</font>
sprite.advancednotes: Appears to need a corresponding Path, and the sprite must be placed to the left of the player's Entrance. Even still, the Sprite doesn't seem to function, possibly due to missing Node ID related functions.

value.title: Path ID
value.advancedcomment: This is intended to pair the Mega Wiggler to a Path.

sprite.name: Donut Ledge
sprite.notes: A cliff-walking donut-style platform that will fall if a player stands on it for too long.

sprite.name: (Unused) Water Current Controller
sprite.notes: This will cause all Water in the Zone to have a current effect applied to it.

dependency.notes: This sprite seems to only function with the [138] version of Water, but will work with Location and Moving versions of it.

dualbox.comment: This determines the direction of the current.
dualbox.comment2: <font color="red">Bug: Penguin suit will always be pushed right.</font>

value.title: Current Force
value.comment: This determines the strength of the current.

sprite.name: Incomplete Sprite - 'Hana_Mountain'
sprite.notes: Does nothing.

sprite.name: Incomplete Sprite - 'River_Mgr'
sprite.notes: Does nothing.

sprite.name: Incomplete Sprite - 'Tag_Thunder'
sprite.notes: Does nothing.

sprite.name: (Unused) Cheep Cheep Formation Spawner
sprite.notes: This will create groups of Cheep Cheeps with certain creation rules that will generate formations.

dependency.notes: This sprite pretty much only works properly with an underwater stage. Placement is determined by the formation used. Its direction should also match the direction the player is most likely to approach from. As such, an auto-scrolling stage is likely most compatible with this sprite.

list.title: Formation Type
list.comment: This determines the type or shape of the formation.
list.comment2:
The Direction in which the formation points is set by the swimming Direction. Cheep Cheep Formations that swim to the right will appear mirrored. All Values ​​after 4 are exactly the same. The arrow formation Value of 1 is different from the remaining ones. It always includes 3 Cheep Cheeps, no matter what else has been set.
Values w/*: This simply means that the number of Cheep Cheeps is ignored (with always only 1 Cheep Cheep per row) when 'Stretch Vertically' is enabled.

Original position:
0, 1, ≥ 5: The Sprite's placement represents the peak of the arrow formation.
2: The Sprite's placement represents the topmost Cheep Cheep in the first row.
3, 4: The Sprite's placement represents the Cheep Cheep that swims in first place.

list.title: Formation Repeat
list.comment: Value + 1. Sets how many groups (rows) appear in succession. 0 = 1 group, 1 = 2 groups with the same pattern appear one after the other, 2 = 3 groups, etc. For groups with an arrow pattern (0 ≥ 5, 1) there is a space of 3 Blocks between groups. For other Values (2, 3, 4) there is only 1 Block of free space between two groups.

list.title: Cheep Cheeps per Formation
list.comment: Value + 1. Number of Cheep Cheeps in a row of each formation (pattern). Every new Cheep Cheeps will either be placed under the last Cheep Cheep (Formation: 2) or after the last Cheep Cheep with a shift on the Y-axis (Formation: 0, 1, 3, 4, 5). The vertical and horizontal distance between the new and the previous Cheep Cheep is one Block. Only for the arrow formations, the shift of the next Cheep Cheeps on the Y-axis is halved.

dualbox.comment: This determines which direction the formation will swim in.
dualbox.comment2: The formation will only spawn correctly if the player approaches it from the direction the formation wants to swim in.

checkbox.title: Stretch Vertically
checkbox.comment: This option determines the displacement of the individual Cheep Cheeps on the Y-axis. If this option is selected, the vertical spacing varies between adjacent Cheep Cheeps It changes periodically (IE, repeatedly) between 0 Blocks and one Block back and forth. The Cheep Cheep will swims straight at the height of the Sprite's placement. Needs about 6 ticks of the level's clock for one pass (IE, once back and forth).

sprite.name: Horizontal Scroll Limiter - Top
sprite.notes: The same Values ​​are listed as the Vertical Scroll Limiter (162, 163, 164, 165). This sprite allows you to limit how far the camera will scroll horizontally by creating an imaginary horizontal border between a matching pair of Scroll Limiters. This can be used to create a deeper kill zone, hide secret areas, or otherwise restrict the camera in certain sections of a level.

dependency.notes: Place this at the top of the area you want to limit, and place an identical [249] at the bottom (same X position). This will create an independent, vertical zone border located at the X position of the Limit pair's placement.

value.title: Revoke Horizontal Scroll Limit (Top)
value.comment: I don't know? Is apparently a VALUE, 0, 1, 2, 3+?

dualbox.comment: This determines which camera boundary will be restricted by this Limit pair.

checkbox.title: Permeable Scroll Limit
checkbox.comment: I know what purpose this has but this description sounds excessive and confusing. I need it boiled down!
checkbox.comment2: With this option, two new specific 'areas' are specified, above and below the scroll limit ('default area' and 'secret area'). Both areas touch the scroll border from the outside. If the bottom of a player's collision box leaves the original (default) area, the screen will quickly 'jump' to this new (secret) area. The shifting is independent of the height of the screen limit. The screen will be pushed up/down as far as needed, until the bottom of the screen is a certain number of blocks above/below the end of the original screen limit. || The required number of blocks between the bottom of the source region and the bottom of the screen is by default 5 (shifting upward) and 8 (for a downward shift). You can alter these values under 'Zone Settings' (Upper/Lower Bounds). || Shifting from the default area to the secret area above/below the scroll limit can be tweaked by changing values for 'Upper Bounds'. The opposite is true for 'Lower Bounds' (shifting from default area to the secret area below. The increase/decrease of the scrollable area reduces/enlarges the necessary distance to the same extent that is needed to pull off the shifting. |||| If Mario goes back to the default area, the screen will quickly follow and it will be locked to the default area as usual (unless Mario goes above/below the scroll limit once again to reach the secret area)... |||| This option can be used to set up secret zones that can only be seen if Mario reaches a specific position. This technique was used in many older Mario games, e.g. Super Mario Land 3: Wario Land. So if you are located below the screen, nothing happens. Only when jumping over the area, the screen scrolls up so you can hide secret paths there as you like. Similarly, one can also hide secret paths under the screen.

value.title: Scroll Limit Shifting in Restricted Direction
value.comment: I don't know what practical purpose this has?
value.comment2: Determines how far the screen can scroll above/below the scroll limit (in blocks). Somewhat flawed if used together with 'Permeable Scroll Limit'. The position where the scrolling will begin does not differ from a scroll limit with shifting of 0. So it looks as if the screen is scrolling faster with increasing values ​​when Mario approaches it. Even higher values are canceled entirely and have no effect because the scrolling is no longer necessary when the end of the screen is too far above or below the end of the original screen border. Nevertheless, the screen jumps to the end of the scroll border when entering the default area again. Only if the bottom of the screen is too far beyond the original area (or vice versa), then the screen is already at the end of the scroll border, and no shifting of the screen is needed.

checkbox.title: Unknown Flag 6 (1)
checkbox.advancedcomment: Used in Retail: 02-01 A1, 05-24 A1, 06-02 A4. May be Multiplayer related?

value.title: Unknown Value 10
value.advancedcomment: From ASM: An independent effect differing from [Permeable Scroll Limit]. Details have not been researched.

value.title: Unknown Value 12
value.advancedcomment: From ASM: An independent effect differing from [Permeable Scroll Limit]. Details have not been researched.

sprite.name: Horizontal Scroll Limiter - Bottom
sprite.notes: The same Values ​​are listed as the Vertical Scroll Limiter (162, 163, 164, 165). This sprite allows you to limit how far the camera will scroll horizontally by creating an imaginary horizontal border between a matching pair of Scroll Limiters. This can be used to create a deeper kill zone, hide secret areas, or otherwise restrict the camera in certain sections of a level.

dependency.notes: Place this at the bottom of the area you want to limit, and place an identical [248] at the top (same X position). This will create an independent, vertical zone border located at the X position of the Limit pair's placement.

value.title: Revoke Horizontal Scroll Limit (Bottom)
value.comment: I don't know? Is apparently a VALUE, 0, 1, 2, 3+?

dualbox.comment: This determines which camera boundary will be restricted by this Limit pair.

checkbox.title: Permeable Scroll Limit
checkbox.comment: I know what purpose this has but this description sounds excessive and confusing. I need it boiled down!
checkbox.comment2: With this option, two new specific 'areas' are specified, above and below the scroll limit ('default area' and 'secret area'). Both areas touch the scroll border from the outside. If the bottom of a player's collision box leaves the original (default) area, the screen will quickly 'jump' to this new (secret) area. The shifting is independent of the height of the screen limit. The screen will be pushed up/down as far as needed, until the bottom of the screen is a certain number of blocks above/below the end of the original screen limit. || The required number of blocks between the bottom of the source region and the bottom of the screen is by default 5 (shifting upward) and 8 (for a downward shift). You can alter these values under 'Zone Settings' (Upper/Lower Bounds). || Shifting from the default area to the secret area above/below the scroll limit can be tweaked by changing values for 'Upper Bounds'. The opposite is true for 'Lower Bounds' (shifting from default area to the secret area below. The increase/decrease of the scrollable area reduces/enlarges the necessary distance to the same extent that is needed to pull off the shifting. |||| If Mario goes back to the default area, the screen will quickly follow and it will be locked to the default area as usual (unless Mario goes above/below the scroll limit once again to reach the secret area)... |||| This option can be used to set up secret zones that can only be seen if Mario reaches a specific position. This technique was used in many older Mario games, e.g. Super Mario Land 3: Wario Land. So if you are located below the screen, nothing happens. Only when jumping over the area, the screen scrolls up so you can hide secret paths there as you like. Similarly, one can also hide secret paths under the screen.

value.title: Scroll Limit Shifting in Restricted Direction
value.comment: I don't know what practical purpose this has?
value.comment2: Determines how far the screen can scroll above/below the scroll limit (in blocks). Somewhat flawed if used together with 'Permeable Scroll Limit'. The position where the scrolling will begin does not differ from a scroll limit with shifting of 0. So it looks as if the screen is scrolling faster with increasing values ​​when Mario approaches it. Even higher values are canceled entirely and have no effect because the scrolling is no longer necessary when the end of the screen is too far above or below the end of the original screen border. Nevertheless, the screen jumps to the end of the scroll border when entering the default area again. Only if the bottom of the screen is too far beyond the original area (or vice versa), then the screen is already at the end of the scroll border, and no shifting of the screen is needed.

checkbox.title: Unknown Flag 6 (1)
checkbox.advancedcomment: Used in Retail: 02-01 A1, 05-24 A1, 06-02 A4. May be Multiplayer related?

value.title: Unknown Value 10
value.advancedcomment: From ASM: An independent effect differing from [Permeable Scroll Limit]. Details have not been researched.

value.title: Unknown Value 12
value.advancedcomment: From ASM: An independent effect differing from [Permeable Scroll Limit]. Details have not been researched.

sprite.name: Incomplete Sprite - 'Kawanagare'
sprite.notes: Does nothing.

sprite.name: Incomplete Sprite - 'Slow_Quick_Tag'
sprite.notes: Does nothing.

sprite.name: Rotation Controlled Event Deactivation Block
sprite.notes: When struck, this ?-Block will deactivate the Target Event. It can also appear through use of a Rotation Controller allowing it to be hidden from sight before hand.

dependency.notes: This sprite must have both a Target Event set and a matching Rotation Controller in order to function. As the block cannot be struck while actively moving, it is only compatible with an Event Activated Swinging Rotation Controller.

value.title: Target Event ID
value.comment: When struck, this ?-Block will deactivate this Event. It must be completely stationary in order to perform this function.
value.comment2: Tip: You can Event Controllers to cause this to indirectly activate an Event instead.

value.title: Rotation ID
value.comment: This pairs the ?-Block to a matching rotation controller.

value.title: Number of Uses
value.comment: This determines the number of times the ?-Block can be struck before it becomes 'used'.
value.comment2: If it is set to 0, the block can be hit any number of times.

sprite.name: Rotation Controlled Coin
sprite.notes: A standard coin that can be paired with rotation controllers. It does not have any additional features like [147] Coin.

dependency.notes: This coin does not function and cannot be collected unless actually paired to a rotation controller.

value.title: Rotation ID
value.comment: This pairs the Coin to a matching rotation controller.

sprite.name: Rotation Controlled Pipe (Buggy)
sprite.notes: A pipe that can be moved by a rotation controller. It can also be a functional entrance (exit) with the right settings.

dependency.notes: Use of this pipe is not recommended. First, in order for it to be functional, it must be paired with an Event Controlled [149] Spinning rotation controller. You must set the pipe up on the grid with a properly placed Entrance located at the post-rotation position. It can then be rotated into that position through events. Any rotation other than 180° results in unpredictable or unpleasant bugs. Additionally, when rotated, the pipe destroys tiles in its way. This behavior can be circumvented by using [169] Magic Platform. Lastly, this supposedly does not pair with a [96] Swaying rotation controller, but a modern test has not been done in regards to using it that way as level decoration.

value.title: Rotation ID
value.comment: This pairs the Pipe to a matching sprite 149 rotation controller.

list.title: Direction
list.comment: This determines which direction the pipe will face. Note that the pipe will rotate from its base.

list.title: Length
list.comment: This determines the length of the pipe.

sprite.name: Rotation Controlled ? Block
sprite.notes: A ?-Block that can either be moved by rotation controllers or manually angled.

dependency.notes: A rotation controller is not required for this sprite to function. You can, instead, set a manual angle for the block.

value.title: Rotation ID
value.comment: This pairs the ?-Block to a matching rotation controller.

list.title: Tilt Angle
list.comment: This determines the angle the block will be tilted. Tilted blocks can not be rotation controlled.

list.title: Block Contains
list.comment: This determines what item the block contains.
list.comment2: This block will release as many items as there are players. Some items, such as the Spring, won't appear if the player strikes the Block while it is actively rotating.

sprite.name: Rotation Controlled Brick Block
sprite.notes: A Brick Block that can either be moved by rotation controllers or manually angled.

dependency.notes: A rotation controller is not required for this sprite to function. You can, instead, set a manual angle for the block.

value.title: Rotation ID
value.comment: This pairs the Brick Block to a matching rotation controller.

list.title: Tilt Angle
list.comment: This determines the angle the block will be tilted. Tilted blocks can not be rotation controlled.

list.title: Block Contains
list.comment: This determines what item the block contains.
list.comment2: This block will only release one power-up item. Some items, such as the Spring, won't appear if the player strikes the Block while it is actively rotating.

sprite.name: Move-When-On Lava Glow Metal Block
sprite.notes: A tall block with the glow of lava underneath it that will move at any point when a specified number of 'passengers' (players + enemies) are standing on it, and then moves back up to its original position when that number drops below the requirement.

list.title: Size
list.comment: This determines the size of the block.

list.title: Moves with Passenger Number
list.comment: This determines how many 'passengers' are needed for the block's movement to activate.
list.comment2: A passenger can be many things. Examples include the players themselves, Goombas and other enemies, and even loose coins created by Fire Flowers.

list.title: Direction
list.comment: This determines which direction the block will move while moving.

value.title: Speed
value.comment: This determines how quickly the block will move while moving.

sprite.name: Bulber Spawn Area
sprite.notes: Assigns a spawn area where Bulbers will continue to swim across the screen from the right towards the player while they are inside it. They will light up the area around them if the lights are off.

dependency.notes: Bulbers do not require non-location water in order to spawn, but as it is a fish, water is suggested. Dimmed or dark lighting is also suggested to take advantage of its lighting effect.

value.title: Location ID
value.comment: The Bulbers will spawn from the right side of the screen, swimming across it only while a player is within this location.

sprite.name: D-Pad Door
sprite.notes: A standard door with a D-Pad symbol on it that can have an Entrance placed on it.
sprite.advancednotes: The door can also be paired with a Rotation Controller, but the results are moderately glitchy with many combinations not functioning and several restrictions on getting them to work as actual doors.

list.title: Orientation
list.comment: This determines which direction the door will be facing.
list.comment2: A door can only be entered if it is upright.
list.advancedcomment: As decoration, this is fine. Actually making it properly associate its corresponding Entrance is either impossible or very functionally strange.

checkbox.title: Rotation Controlled (Buggy)
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the door will only function when paired with a Rotation ID.
checkbox.advancedcomment: 'Function' is perhaps misleading. There are only a few ways you can successfully utilize a Rotation Controller door. For starters, you can only enter the door while it is almost fully upright. There is also a peculiarity with how the Entrance is placed. The most reliable way to use a Rotation Controlled Door is to place it with an already activated Spinning controller that returns to its original position when deactivated.

value.title: Rotation ID
value.comment: This pairs the Door to a matching rotation controller.

sprite.name: Movement Controller - Two Way Line
sprite.notes: This controller will create synchronized movement between matched sprites and cause them to move in two-way line back and forth. A delay can be specified on each end of this movement.

value.title: Two Way Line ID
value.comment: This pairs matching Two Way Line controlled objects to this controller.

list.title: Movement Direction
list.comment: This determines which direction the linked objects will move before returning to their starting locations.

list.title: Speed
list.comment: This determines how quickly the linked objects will move.

value.title: Delay Before Movement
value.comment: This determines how long the linked objects will wait before making their outwards movement.

value.title: Distance Moved
value.comment: This determines how far the linked objects will move.

value.title: Delay Before Return
value.comment: This determines how long the linked objects will wait before making their return movement.

checkbox.title: Event Activated
checkbox.comment: This determines if the movement will happen only if a specified Event is activated.
checkbox.comment2: <font color="red">An important note about using Event Activation:</font> Once activated, this movement cannot be turned off unless the player reenters the Zone with the Event deactivated. Additionally, platforms that use Two Way Line movement will not show unless the Event is activated. Coins and Blocks, however, will display.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: This determines the Event that, when activated, will enable the Two Way Line movement synchronization.

sprite.name: Grey Tiled Block - Two Way Line
sprite.notes: This is a resizable stone block that was not used in retail NSMBW. This version can have Two Way Line synchronized movement applied to it.

dependency.notes: This block must be paired with a [260] Two Way Line movement controller in order to appear and function.

value.title: Two Way Line ID
value.comment: This pairs the block to a matching Two Way Line movement controller.

list.title: Height
list.comment: This determines how tall the block is.

list.title: Width
list.comment: This determines how wide the block is.

sprite.name: Poltergeist Item
sprite.notes: A haunted item that appears identical to its normal counterparts until a player either comes close enough or until they enter a specific Location.

dualbox.comment: This determines which object will be haunted.

value.title: Activation Delay
value.comment: This determines how long after being triggered the poltergeist will wait before hurling the object at the player.
value.comment2: If you discover the multiple of the delay value that equals one game second, let us know.

value.title: Location ID
value.comment: When set, the haunted object will only be activated if a player enters this location.
value.comment2: Assigning a Location is not required. If one is not set, the item will instead be triggered by the proximity of the player.

sprite.name: Lily Piranha Plant
sprite.notes: A floating piranha plant that balances a spiky spore ball in the air above it.

dependency.notes: The piranha plant must be placed inside or on the surface of water [138] to spawn. It will snap to the surface when loaded on-screen.

checkbox.title: Disable Collisions After Death
checkbox.comment: When Lily Piranhas die and sink, they bounce when they hit a solid tile, such as a wall. This flag disables that behavior.

sprite.name: Stalking Piranha Plant
sprite.notes: A walking piranha plant that will extend and harass the player, then shrink and wander around for a bit.

dualbox.comment: This determines which direction the piranha plant will attempt to move first after shrinking.

value.title: Movement Distance
value.comment: This determines how far the piranha plant will wander in both directions from its starting point.

checkbox.title: Slower in Water
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the piranha plant will walk more slowly when moving through water.

checkbox.title: Increase Z-pos by 200
checkbox.comment: When ticked, the piranha plant's z position will be 200 higher.

sprite.name: Falling Icicle
sprite.notes: A small hanging icicle that will fall when the player comes too close (8 blocks horizontally) to it. It will hurt the player, regardless of where he touches it. When hit by a [388] Barrel, a nice break effect is used. Shells can also break them, but don't use a break effect.

list.title: Parent / Child
list.comment: Parent icicles will fall, Child icicles will never fall.
list.comment2: Any nonzero value causes 'child' behaviour. Parent icicles are actually invisible and never fall either. Instead, parent icicles create child icicles that they activate when a player gets nearby.

checkbox.title: Growing animation
checkbox.comment: When ticked, the icicle uses an initial growing animation.
checkbox.comment2: Each frame, the scale is increased by 1/240. So it takes 240 frames (4 seconds) to grow.

list.title: Size
list.comment: The size of the icicle. Higher values cause crashes.

sprite.name: Rotating Chainlink Fence Wheel
sprite.notes: The fence draws behind Layer 1 by default.

dualbox.comment: This determines which direction the wheel will spin in.

list.title: Speed
list.comment: This determines how fast the wheel will spin.

sprite.name: Tilt Controlled Chainlink Fence
sprite.notes: A Chainlink Fence object with tilt control that will be assigned to the first player to touch it. Once assigned, it can be moved in a circular manner by tilting the Wiimote.

list.title: Orientation
list.comment: This determines the default location of the Chainlink Fence panel.

list.title: Rotational Limit - Clockwise
list.comment: This determines how far from the original position the Chainlink Fence panel can rotate in the clockwise direction.
list.comment2: If using No Limit, the panel can rotate forever in the clockwise direction, but the panel must 'un-rotate' once the player jumps off for the panel to be usable again. As such, it's not recommended.

list.title: Rotational Limit - Counter-Clockwise
list.comment: This determines how far from the original position the Chainlink Fence panel can rotate in the counter-clockwise direction.
list.comment2: If using No Limit, the panel can rotate forever in the counter-clockwise direction, but the panel must 'un-rotate' once the player jumps off for the panel to be usable again. As such, it's not recommended.

sprite.name: Lava Geyser
sprite.notes: An eruption of lava that will block a player's path.

dependency.notes: While it is not required, it is recommended to place the geyser partially submerged in Lava of some form.

list.title: Geyser Height
list.comment: This determines how high the geyser will erupt.

dualbox.comment: This determines the state of the geyser when it first loads on the screen.

list.title: Eruption Length
list.comment: This determines how long the geyser will erupt.

list.title: Delay Between Eruptions
list.comment: This determines how long the geyser will wait between eruptions.

sprite.name: Parachute Bob-Omb
sprite.notes: A parachuting Bob-Omb enemy that will turn into a standard Bob-Omb after it lands.

dependency.notes: The Y-position of the Bob-Omb has no effect. It will always appear directly above the top edge of the screen.

sprite.name: Parachute Bob-Omb Spawn Area
sprite.notes: Assigns a spawn area where parachuting Bob-Ombs will fall from the sky while a player is inside it.

value.title: Location ID
value.comment: The parachuting Bob-Ombs will only spawn while a player is in this location.

list.title: Spawn Delay
